questions.text: A newborn boy delivered at 38 weeks gestation is found to be in respiratory distress 4 hours after delivery. The pregnancy and delivery were without complications. APGAR scores were 5 and 7 respectively, at 1 and 5 minutes. Temperature is 36.8�C (98.2�F), heart rate is 210/min, respiratory rate is 60/min, blood pressure is 60/30 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 82% on room air. On physical examination, the skin is gray, cool, and mottled, there is central cyanosis and subcostal retractions are observed. Pulmonary exam is within normal limits. Cardiac examination is significant for a single loud S2 without murmur. There are weak peripheral pulses bilaterally. The newborn is intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation and an umbilical line is inserted for intravenous fluids. Chest X-ray shows cardiomegaly and pulmonary venous congestion. An echocardiogram reveals a hypoplastic left atrium and ventricle. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This newborn is found to have central cyanosis and respiratory distress a few hours after birth. There is tachypnea, weak peripheral pulses, and a single S2 on examination. Chest x-ray shows pulmonary venous congestion and cardiomegaly consistent with hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS). An echocardiogram showing hypoplastic left atrium and ventricle confirms the diagnosis. HLHS is a ductal-dependent lesion, and patients require intravenous prostaglandin (PGE) infusion to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) to provide adequate systemic circulation while awaiting surgery within the first two weeks of life.        

HLHS is a cyanotic congenital heart disease (CHD) where there is severe atresia of the mitral and aortic valves resulting in decreased blood flow from the left atrium into the left ventricle (LV) and from the LV into the aorta, resulting in a hypoplastic LA and LV. If the duct is left to close patients will have signs of poor systemic perfusion including weak pulses, poor urine output, shock, and skin mottling, in addition to signs and symptoms of pulmonary over-circulation like tachypnea and respiratory distress.         

Chest radiographs will show pulmonary vascular congestion and cardiomegaly due to right ventriculomegaly. Echocardiogram will show hypoplastic left atrium and ventricle; mitral valve or aortic root atresia, right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH), and an atrial septal defect (ASD) or patent foramen ovale (PFO).    

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous antibiotics :
Incorrect: Intravenous antibiotics should be started in neonates with sepsis. This neonate has hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) and requires intravenous prostaglandins (PGE) to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) for adequate systemic circulation.  
✅ Intravenous prostaglandin infusion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Genetic consultation :
Incorrect: Genetic consultation should be offered to families of neonatal patients with hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) and features of Turner syndrome (e.g., webbed neck, lymphedema, and wide-spaced nipples), however, this patient requires prompt administration of intravenous PGE to keep the PDA open.  
❌ Surgical correction  :
Incorrect: Surgical correction of hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) occurs in multiple stages beginning within the first 2 weeks after birth. This patient with HLHS should be promptly started on intravenous prostaglandin to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) to maintain systemic circulation while awaiting surgery.  
❌ Cardiac catheterization  :
Incorrect: Cardiac catheterization with balloon atrial septostomy can help neonatal patients with transposition of the greater arteries while awaiting surgery. The findings of hypoplastic left atrium and ventricle on echocardiogram are consistent with hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) which requires prompt administration of intravenous prostaglandins to maintain the patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and adequate systemic circulation.

questions.text:
A 4-month-old girl is brought to the clinic for a well-child visit. Her parents report that her lips turn blue when she is crying vigorously, and they return to normal color once she stops crying. She was delivered at 37 weeks' gestation. The pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and the parent and fetus had routine prenatal care. The infant is breastfeeding and at times she takes a long time to feed. All immunizations are up-to-date. Temperature is 36.8�C (98.2�F), heart rate is 170/min, respiratory rate is 45/min, blood pressure is 85/47 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 81% on room air while crying. Physical examination reveals central cyanosis when the infant is crying. Cardiac examination is significant for a grade 3/6 harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard along the left sternal border that radiates to the axillae and back. The rest of the physical examination is within normal limits. Chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?



Reproduced from: Statdx
questions.solution:
This patient who presents at 4 months with episodic cyanosis brought on by crying is found to have a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur and a boot-shaped heart on chest x-ray. The most likely diagnosis is tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). Cyanotic spells triggered by agitation or illness that resolve spontaneously are suggestive of paroxysmal hypercyanotic attacks, or tet spells. Difficulty feeding and physical examination findings of low oxygen saturation and a harsh high-intensity systolic murmur (radiating to the axillae or back), along with a “boot-shaped” heart seen on the chest x-ray are all consistent with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).         

Patients with TOF most commonly present within the first few months of life with a systolic murmur with or without associated hypercyanotic (Tet) spells and low oxygen saturation. Tet spells can occur when there is increased right ventricular outflow tract obstruction, increased pulmonary vascular resistance, or decreased systemic vascular resistance which promotes increased shunting from the right ventricle to the left ventricle, causing more mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood resulting in severe cyanosis. These spells are often triggered by agitation or illness. They usually resolve by calming the infant, administering oxygen, and placing the infant in the knee-to-chest position, but some may require medication.        

The timing of symptoms in patients with TOF depends on the severity of the right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. TOF has 4 main components; overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect (VSD), pulmonary stenosis, and right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). Echocardiogram findings of an overriding aorta with VSD, pulmonary stenosis, and RVH confirm the diagnosis of TOF.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hypoplastic left heart syndrome  :
Incorrect: Hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) is a ductal-dependent lesion that results in central cyanosis and respiratory distress within a few hours after birth. With Cardiomegaly seen on chest x-ray. This patient’s age, episodes of cyanosis with crying, difficulty feeding, harsh systolic murmur, and chest x-ray finding of a “boot-shaped” heart are consistent with tetralogy of Fallot.  
✅ Tetralogy of Fallot:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Transposition of the great arteries  :
Incorrect: Patients with transposition of the great arteries develop symptoms within the first 12 hours of life. They present with tachypnea, a loud single S2, and a chest X-ray with the pathognomonic "egg on a string" appearance. This patient’s age, episodes of cyanosis with crying, difficulty feeding, harsh systolic murmur, and chest x-ray finding of a “boot-shaped” heart are consistent with tetralogy of Fallot. 
❌ Tricuspid atresia  :
Incorrect: Patients with Tricuspid atresia present shortly after birth with severe cyanosis, a single S2, and chest X-ray that demonstrates decreased pulmonary blood flow and cardiomegaly. This patient’s age, cyanotic spells, difficulty feeding, harsh systolic murmur, and chest x-ray finding of a “boot-shaped” heart are consistent with tetralogy of Fallot. 
❌ Total anomalous pulmonary venous return  :
Incorrect: Patients with total anomalous pulmonary venous return present with profound respiratory distress. They do not have a murmur on cardiac examination, and chest X-ray shows a characteristic "snowman" appearance. This patient’s age, episodes of cyanosis with crying, difficulty feeding, harsh systolic murmur, and chest x-ray finding of a “boot-shaped” heart are consistent with tetralogy of Fallot.

questions.text:
Six hours ago, a newborn girl was delivered via uncomplicated vaginal delivery at 37 weeks of estimated gestation age. She is cyanotic and is having difficulty feeding in the newborn nursery. The pregnancy was uncomplicated, and the mother had regular prenatal care. The rupture of membrane was six hours prior to delivery, group B streptococcus (GBS) was negative, and amniotic fluid was clear. APGAR scores were 6 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) and stable, pulse is 210/min, respirations are 55/min, blood pressure is 63/39 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 85% at the right hand and 86% at the left foot. Physical exam shows no dysmorphic features but reveals cyanotic mucous membranes and extremities. There is mild nasal flaring, and intercostal retractions are seen. Cardiac exam reveals a single loud second heart sound and harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left sternal border. On pulmonary exam, air entry is equal bilaterally and normal breath sounds are heard throughout. The abdomen is soft without hepatosplenomegaly. Pulses are equal and symmetrical bilaterally. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step for confirming the diagnosis?
 

Statdx
questions.solution:
This newborn with central cyanosis and physical exam findings of low oxygen saturation, a harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left sternal border, and a single loud S2 along with a chest X-ray showing “boot-shaped" heart and SpO2 of less than 90% in the right hand and left foot likely has Tetralogy of Fallot. An echocardiogram should be performed to help confirm the diagnosis.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a critical congenital heart disease that presents with findings secondary to decreased pulmonary blood flow. Patients typically develop cyanosis and shortness of breath shortly after birth or in the first few months of life, depending on the severity. TOF has 4 components: overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect (VSD), pulmonary stenosis, and right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). History may reveal cardiac defects on prenatal ultrasound. Physical exam may show central cyanosis, a harsh systolic ejection murmur on left sternal border, and low oxygen saturation as are seen in this patient.  

Newborns with central cyanosis should be evaluated for cardiac and non-cardiac causes. To help differentiate the etiology of central cyanosis, pulse oximetry for pre- and post-ductal saturations should be checked to determine if congenital heart disease is likely. Pulse oximetry measurements on the right-hand measure pre-ductal saturation, and pulse oximetry measurements on either foot measure post-ductal saturation.  

Criteria for echocardiogram to rule out cyanotic congenital heart disease includes SpO2 less than 90% in the right hand and foot, SpO2 less than 95% in right hand and foot on three separate occasions, or a difference of 3% or higher between the pre- and post-ductal oxygen saturations on three separate occasions. If pre-ductal saturations are significantly higher than post-ductal saturations, this means that de-oxygenated blood is being shunted from the pulmonary artery to the aorta through an open ductus arteriosus. This is called differential cyanosis. If any of these criteria are met, echocardiogram is necessary to evaluate the patient for critical congenital heart disease. If echocardiogram is normal or criteria are not met, consider other etiologies of cyanosis, such as pulmonary causes, upper airway obstruction, respiratory depression, neonatal sepsis, or hemorrhagic shock.    

Option Analysis

❌ Complete blood count :
Incorrect: Complete blood count (CBC) is useful for determining neonatal sepsis and hemorrhagic shock; both may cause central cyanosis in newborns. This patient's physical and radiological findings suggest a cyanotic congenital heart disease, and an echocardiogram should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Blood culture:
Incorrect: Blood culture can help confirm the diagnosis of neonatal sepsis in patients with fever and risk factors for neonatal sepsis. This patient's physical and radiological findings suggest a cyanotic congenital heart disease, and an echocardiogram should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. 
✅ Echocardiogram  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Head ultrasound  :
Incorrect: Head ultrasound should be obtained in newborns with decreased respiratory effort, history of maternal opioid use, birth trauma, and hypotonia to rule out intracranial hemorrhage. This patient's physical and radiological findings suggest a cyanotic congenital heart disease, and an echocardiogram should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.  
❌ Nasopharyngoscopy :
Incorrect: Nasopharyngoscopy is helpful for diagnosing upper airway obstruction, such as choanal atresia, vocal cord paralysis, and vascular malformations, as the cause of cyanosis with stridor or stertor in the newborn. These findings are not noted in this patient, making upper airway obstruction unlikely.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man comes to the emergency department with two weeks of fevers and chills. He also reports a poor appetite and has noticed a weight loss of 2.3 kg (5 lb) over the past month. He also complains of malaise with intermittent headaches, muscle aches, and night sweats over this same time period. Medical history is significant for chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage II, due to hypertension. Medications include lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. He was born in India, and he does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. His temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 100/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. He appears ill. Physical exam shows a regularly irregular heartbeat with a high-pitched, early diastolic decrescendo murmur. Lung auscultation reveals crackles at the bilateral lung bases. Laboratory studies show renal function at baseline and normal cardiac enzymes. An ECG is obtained and shows the following:  



 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s ECG shows second-degree Mobitz type II atrioventricular (AV) block. This heart block is characterized by “all-or-nothing” conduction of electrical impulses through the AV node, leading to dropped beats that appear as a P wave without a subsequent QRS complex. Compared to the lengthening PR intervals in second-degree Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) AV block, Mobitz type II AV block demonstrates a stable PR interval.



Causes of Mobitz type II AV block overlap with the causes of other AV blocks, including myocardial ischemia, cardiomyopathy (e.g., amyloidosis, sarcoidosis), myocarditis (e.g. Lyme disease), hyperkalemia, and medication effects. This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of infective endocarditis, including high fevers, night sweats, anorexia, weight loss, and myalgias. Infective endocarditis of the aortic valve may lead to a periannular abscess at the base of the valve, which places pressure on the adjacent AV node, leading to heart block. An abscess in this location may also lead to aortic insufficiency, which is consistent with the murmur present on this patient’s exam.  

Initial management of all patients with Mobitz type II AV block involves the placement of transcutaneous pacer pads, as this block may cause profound bradycardia and progress to third-degree heart block at any time. If no reversible cause is found, patients will require permanent pacemaker implantation.    

Option Analysis

❌  Left heart catheterization:
Incorrect: Left heart catheterization lets interventional cardiologists visualize the anatomy and patency of the coronary arteries and deploy stents to obstructed vessels. Patients with acutely obstructed coronary arteries who need left heart catheterization would instead present with ST-segment changes and elevated cardiac enzymes.  
❌ Intubation:
Incorrect: Patients with acute or worsening hypoxia, severely altered mental status, or airway obstruction should be intubated to provide mechanical ventilation while the underlying problem is fixed. This patient has a peripheral oxygen saturation greater than 90% on room air and does not require mechanical ventilation.  
❌ Defibrillation:
Incorrect: Defibrillation refers to the application of electricity across the chest to shock the heart back into sinus rhythm, and it only works on ventricular tachycardia (VT) and ventricular fibrillation (VF). Defibrillating a patient who does not have VT of VF can cause a deadly arrhythmia.  
✅ Transcutaneous pacing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ No treatment is required:
Incorrect: Second-degree type II AV block is a dangerous arrhythmia that can develop into complete heart block and cause circulatory collapse at any time. It must be treated urgently and will require pacemaker placement.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of new-onset hoarseness. The patient reports worsening hoarseness over several weeks without a precipitating cause. The patient has had no difficulty swallowing liquids or solids. He has a history of long-standing hypertension, mitral valve stenosis, and a twenty-pack-year smoking history. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates an irregular heartbeat. A screening electrocardiogram is shown below. Which of the following structures is most likely implicated in this patient’s symptomatology?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with a longstanding history of hypertension and mitral valve stenosis presents with symptoms of compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve, likely secondary to left atrial enlargement. Left atrial enlargement often results in atrial fibrillation, as detailed on this patient’s electrocardiogram.

Left atrial enlargement can occur secondary to mitral regurgitation, left ventricular dysfunction, mitral stenosis, or volume overload. Over time, increased pressure dilates the left atrium, stretching the conduction fibers and resulting in atrial fibrillation. This enlargement can also compress nearby structures including the esophagus and left recurrent laryngeal nerve, which can manifest as dysphagia or hoarseness, respectively.  



Option Analysis

✅ Left recurrent laryngeal nerve :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Phrenic nerve :
Incorrect: The phrenic nerve is less commonly involved in cases of left atrial enlargement. Symptoms of phrenic nerve injury include exertional dyspnea, recurrent pneumonia, anxiety, insomnia, morning headache, excessive daytime somnolence, orthopnea, fatigue, or difficulty weaning from mechanical ventilation. 
❌ Esophagus:
Incorrect: The esophagus and the left recurrent laryngeal nerve may be affected in cases of left atrial enlargement. However, this patient does not have evidence of dysphagia, suggesting an absence of esophageal compression.
❌ Pulmonary vein :
Incorrect: Injury to the pulmonary vein can occur following cardiac ablation procedures, which can result in pulmonary hypertension. However, this patient has not undergone cardiac ablation, and he does not have signs of pulmonary hypertension. Hoarseness is more consistent with recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
❌ Tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: Cardiac ablation procedures can result in direct cardiac damage, including injury to the tricuspid valve. However, this patient has not undergone a cardiac ablation, and hoarseness is more consistent with recurrent laryngeal nerve injury. Additionally, injury to the tricuspid valve would manifest with a systolic murmur, which is absent in this patient.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of difficulty swallowing. Over the past several weeks, the patient has had the sensation of “food getting stuck” as he swallows. He also has a new history of intermittent “jitteriness.” Medical history is notable for long-standing hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and esophageal reflux. The patient’s medications include metoprolol, metformin, atorvastatin, and omeprazole. He has a history of medication non-compliance. Temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 177/92 mmHg. The patient’s physical examination is unremarkable. A portion of the patient’s telemetry strip is demonstrated below. Which of the following best describes the affected anatomic site that most likely resulted in this patient’s clinical symptoms?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Level of the left main bronchus

questions.solution:
This patient presents for dysphagia evaluation and is found to have new-onset atrial fibrillation. Although rare, atrial fibrillation and associated left atrial dilation can result in compression of the esophagus and subsequent food impaction.  

The esophagus has multiple compression sites as it courses from the oropharynx to the stomach. Superiorly, the esophagus may constrict as it enters the mediastinum, where the cricopharyngeus muscle may cause constriction. Thoracic constrictions occur where the arch of the aorta crosses the esophagus or at the levels of the left main bronchus and the left atrium. Lastly, the esophagus may constrict crossing the diaphragm.  

Pathologic insults at any anatomic site can ultimately slow the passage of solid foods and liquids. Over time, these insults can lead to esophageal stricture formation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Level of the left atrium :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Level of the cricopharyngeal muscle:
Incorrect: Food impaction and stricture formation may result at the esophageal level of the cricopharyngeus muscle. However, this patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus. 
❌ Level of the aortic arch :
Incorrect: Aortic arch dilation from aortic dissection or aortic aneurysm may impede the esophagus at this level. However, this patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus. 
❌ Level of the left main bronchus:
Incorrect: Impingement at the level of the left main bronchus may occur from mass effect due to associated trauma or tumor burden. However, this patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus. 
❌ Level of the diaphragm:
Incorrect: Esophageal constriction may occur at the diaphragm level due to long-standing esophageal reflux disease and associated stricture formation. Typically, affected individuals will have evidence of untreated disease, including epigastric pain, a metallic taste in the mouth, or a history of gastritis or peptic ulcer disease. This patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male college student comes to the clinic with an ECG obtained at a health fair, where he was told the reading was abnormal. He is a competitive track and field athlete and excels in long-distance running. He denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or loss of consciousness. He has no prior medical history and takes no medications other than a daily multivitamin. He denies family history of sudden unexpected deaths. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg. He appears thin and comfortable. Physical exam shows a normal heart rate without murmurs and 2+ regular carotid and radial pulses bilaterally. Lungs are clear. ECG shows the following:  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has isolated first degree atrioventricular (AV) block on his ECG. First degree AV block is defined as a PR interval > 200 milliseconds, representing prolonged conduction through the AV node:  





First degree AV block may be caused by heightened vagal tone (e.g. highly conditioned endurance athletes), structural abnormalities of the AV node, medications that impair nodal conduction (e.g., digoxin, beta blockers, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers), conduction pathway infiltration (e.g. sarcoidosis), and ischemia (e.g. inferior wall myocardial infarction, because the AV node is supplied by the right coronary artery).  

The majority of cases of first degree AV block are found incidentally on ECG, are not dangerous, and do not cause symptoms. History and physical examination should be directed toward identifying any of the pathologies described above. In the absence of concerning cardiac findings on exam, asymptomatic patients like this athlete require no further workup or treatment.  

Option Analysis

❌ Perform invasive electrophysiology study:
Incorrect: In patients with isolated first degree AV block, an invasive electrophysiology study (EPS) is not needed for diagnosis. If a wide QRS complex is present concurrently with PR prolongation, the conduction delay may be present below the AV node, and EPS may be helpful to determine the precise location.  
❌ Recommend decreasing physical activity:
Incorrect: Highly conditioned endurance athletes may have evidence of first degree AV block because of increased vagal tone with a lower resting heart rate. In the absence of symptoms, reducing physical activity is unnecessary.   
❌ Perform transthoracic echocardiogram:
Incorrect: All patients with suspected first degree AV blocks should be questioned about a history of heart disease. In the absence of risk factors for heart disease, in an otherwise healthy young patient with first degree AV block, an echocardiogram will not provide helpful information and is unnecessary.  
❌ Place permanent pacemaker  :
Incorrect: A pacemaker is not recommended in asymptomatic patients with first degree AV block.   
✅ No treatment is required:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after developing acute onset, left-sided weakness. The patient’s daughter reports she found her mother sitting in a chair, unable to lift her left arm or leg. The patient’s past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 177/86 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. Neurologic examination demonstrates a right-sided gaze deviation and 2/5 strength in the left upper and left lower extremity. An initial electrocardiogram is shown below. Which of the following structures of the heart is the most common origin of the thrombus implicated in this patient’s clinical condition?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons.
questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of an ischemic stroke–a major complication of untreated atrial fibrillation, which is depicted on this patient’s electrocardiogram.

Atrial fibrillation is the most common sustained arrhythmia in clinical practice and results from unpatterned depolarization of atrial tissues caused by multiple micro-reentry circuits. These reentry circuits can be caused by progressive fibrosis and atrial dilation. Electrocardiographically, atrial fibrillation is characterized by irregular QRS complexes with absent P-waves.   

Diastolic filling and subsequent cardiac output may decrease when rapid ventricular response occurs with rates >100 beats per minute. These changes can result in chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, and lightheadedness. In addition, hemostasis in the atria can result in thrombus formation, most commonly at the left atrial appendage, owing to its shape and internal trabeculations.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Left atrial appendage:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Right ventricle :
Incorrect: The right ventricle is not the most common site of thrombus formation resulting in ischemic stroke. Thrombus formation and subsequent ischemic stroke do not commonly occur from the right heart unless a patent foramen ovale is present. 
❌ Left ventricle:
Incorrect: Left ventricular aneurysms following myocardial infarction can serve as the site of thrombus formation and subsequent ischemic stroke; however, it is not the most common site of thrombus formation. 
❌ Mitral valve:
Incorrect: The left atrial appendage, not the mitral valve, is the most common site of thrombus formation and subsequent ischemic stroke from atrial fibrillation. 
❌ Tricuspid valve :
Incorrect: The tricuspid valve is not the most common site of thrombus formation resulting in ischemic stroke. Thrombus formation and subsequent ischemic stroke do not commonly occur from the right heart unless a patent foramen ovale is present.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with acute-on-chronic decompensated heart failure. He is on intravenous furosemide twice daily, and his shortness of breath and peripheral edema improve. On day 4 of his hospitalization, several episodes of ventricular tachycardia are noted on cardiac telemetry, lasting approximately 10–20 seconds. The patient does not have palpitations or chest pain. Temperature is 36.8 °C (98.2 °F), pulse is 60/min, blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on 2L nasal cannula. His ECG is shown below. Laboratory studies are ordered. Which of the following findings would be expected?
questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing episodes of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (VT). In addition, his ECG shows prominent U waves, which are most commonly associated with severe hypokalemia. This is most likely attributable to the aggressive diuresis with IV furosemide.

Non-sustained VT is a period of VT lasting < 30 seconds. This is differentiated from sustained VT which lasts more than 30 seconds. Patients with nonsustained VT are most often asymptomatic, but some patients may experience palpitations, chest pain, shortness of breath, lightheadedness, or syncope. In contrast to sustained VT, patients with non-sustained VT do not become hemodynamically unstable because the VT terminates spontaneously.

There are many potential reversible causes of nonsustained VT, so an evaluation should include a thorough history and physical examination, ECG, electrolytes, cardiac enzymes, and echocardiography.

The treatment of VT is based on the presentation, ECG findings, and uncovering potentially reversible causes. Treatment options include reperfusion therapy, implantable cardioverter defibrillator, IV potassium, beta-blockers, and catheter ablation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated troponin:
Incorrect: An elevated troponin would be expected in cases of acute coronary syndrome. However, this patient has no chest pain and the ECG does not demonstrate the typical ST segment changes.  
❌ Elevated potassium:
Incorrect: ECG changes in hyperkalemia can vary depending on the severity, but may include peaked T waves, PR prolongation, QRS widening, and loss of P waves. These findings are not present on this patient’s ECG.  
✅ Low potassium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevated calcium:
Incorrect: ECG findings in severe hypercalcemia may include shortened QT interval, J waves, T wave inversions, and heart block. These are not found on this patient’s ECG.  
❌ Low calcium:
Incorrect: The typical ECG finding in hypocalcemia is QT prolongation. This is not evident on this patient’s ECG.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman presents to a primary care clinic with a four-day history of dizziness and lightheadedness. The patient has not had fevers, chest pain, or shortness of breath. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease and hypertension. Medications include aspirin, ramipril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 45 beats/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. An ECG tracing is obtained and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Picture taken from Osmosis Block Notes

choices.text: Mobitz type I second-degree AV block
Mobitz type II second-degree AV block

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a four-day history of dizziness, lightheadedness, and bradycardia and is found to have progressive PR interval prolongation followed by dropped QRS complexes on ECG. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Mobitz type I second-degree AV block. Potential causes of this condition in this patient include ischemic damage to the conduction system and slowing of AV nodal conduction due to metoprolol use.

In the diagnostic workup for an adult with bradycardia, a detailed history and a 12-lead ECG are crucial to differentiate between sinus bradycardia and atrioventricular block.

Sinus bradycardia is defined by a regular, slow sinus rhythm (less than 60 beats per minute) with normal P wave morphology and PR intervals on electrocardiogram (ECG). While it can be a physiological occurrence in physically active individuals, it may also be pathological. Pathological sinus bradycardia can result from factors that lead to sinus node dysfunction, such as age-related sinoatrial exit block, chronotropic incompetence, or sick sinus syndrome. It can also be caused by reversible/physiological factors, including neurogenic, cardiogenic, or metabolic causes.

Atrioventricular (AV) block is a condition characterized by impaired conduction between the atria and ventricles of the heart, which can be classified into three types, each with distinct ECG findings.
 

First-degree AV block presents with a prolonged PR interval with every P wave followed by a QRS complex; the heart rate can be normal or slow, but the rhythm is regular. Second-degree AV block gets divided into two types: Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) presents with progressive prolongation of the PR interval until a P wave is not followed by a QRS complex, after which the pattern repeats. While Mobitz type II presents with intermittent non-conducted P waves without progressive PR interval prolongation. This condition is more likely to progress to complete heart block, potentially requiring a pacemaker. Third-degree AV block, or complete heart block, displays no relationship between P waves and QRS complexes, with P waves occurring at a higher rate than QRS complexes. This condition is usually managed with pacemaker placement.  

Option Analysis

✅ Mobitz type I second-degree AV block:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sinus bradycardia:
Incorrect: Sinus bradycardia is a regular, slow sinus rhythm (<60 beats/min) with normal P wave morphology and constant PR intervals. Although the patient's pulse is slow, the ECG findings of progressive PR interval prolongation until a P wave is not followed by a QRS complex make Mobitz type I second-degree AV block more likely.  
❌ Mobitz type II second-degree AV block:
Incorrect: Mobitz type II second-degree AV block is characterized by a constant PR interval with intermittently non-conducted P waves and dropped QRS complexes. While this patient presents with bradycardia, the ECG findings of progressive PR interval prolongation until a P wave is not followed by a QRS complex are more consistent with Mobitz type I second-degree AV block.  
❌ Third-degree AV block:
Incorrect: Third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block, also known as complete heart block, is characterized by a complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes with P waves occurring at a higher rate than QRS complexes. This patient's ECG findings are more consistent with Mobitz type I second-degree AV block.  
❌ Sick sinus syndrome:
Incorrect: Sick sinus syndrome is characterized by alternating episodes of bradycardia and supraventricular tachycardia, often due to sinus node dysfunction. While this patient has bradycardia, the ECG findings and clinical presentation are more consistent with Mobitz type I second-degree AV block.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for a routine evaluation. He has no acute complaints. On review of history, he endorses intermittent episodes of dizziness and palpitation, which he attributes to natural aging. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and asthma, for which he uses an albuterol inhaler. The patient consumes one pack of cigarettes per day. In the office, his temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 141/83 mmHg, and pulse is 110/min. An EKG is performed and shown below. Cardiac exam reveals an irregular rhythm. The remainder of the physical exam is non-contributory. The patient is started on the first-line rate controlling medication for his condition. Which of the following best describes its mechanism of action?


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Reduction of signal conduction through atrioventricular node

questions.solution:
This patient has a history and EKG findings consistent with atrial fibrillation. Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are a class of vasodilators, or medications that promote dilation of blood vessels, that can be used as a first-line treatment for atrial fibrillation. CCBs can be subdivided into non-dihydropyridine and dihydropyridine CCBs.  

Non-dihydropyridine CCBs (e.g., verapamil, diltiazem) act predominantly at the heart but have minor vasodilatory properties. They are useful in treating tachyarrhythmias, angina, and hypertension. Non-dihydropyridine CCBs decrease SA node discharge rate (reduces heart rate), AV node discharge rate (terminates supraventricular tachycardia), and intracellular calcium (reduces cardiac contractility).  

Dihydropyridine CCBs (e.g., amlodipine, nifedipine) act predominantly at the smooth muscle of blood vessels. They are used to treat hypertension, Raynaud phenomenon, angina pectoris (via coronary artery vasodilation, which increases oxygen supply to cardiac myocytes), and prevent cerebral vasospasm.   


Option Analysis

❌ Relaxation of vascular smooth muscle:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the chief mechanism of action of dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (CCBs), such as nifedipine and amlodipine. These medications can be used to treat hypertension, angina, Raynaud phenomenon, and prevent cerebral vasospasm after a subarachnoid hemorrhage. However, they are rarely used in the treatment of atrial fibrillation.
❌ Selective inhibition of PDE-3 :
Incorrect: Milrinone works via this mechanism of action. Inhibition of PDE-3 leads to increased cAMP levels, which helps increase intracellular calcium and myocyte contractility. The medication is used to treat heart failure, but it is not used in the treatment of atrial fibrillation.
❌ Inhibition of Na+/K+ ATPase pump:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes digoxin’s mechanism of action. Inhibition of the Na+/K+ ATPase pump leads to indirect inhibition of the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. Digoxin ultimately increases intracellular calcium concentrations and cardiac myocyte contractility. However, digoxin is not used as the first-line treatment for atrial fibrillation.
✅ Reduction of signal conduction through atrioventricular node :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Activation of intracellular guanylyl cyclase:
Incorrect: Medications such as nitrates promote vasodilation via this mechanism. The activated guanylyl cyclases increase cGMP concentration, which in turn causes dephosphorylation of myosin light chains. As a result, light chains are unable to interact with actin and vasodilation occurs. Nitrates are not used in the treatment of atrial fibrillation.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. He reports intermittent, squeezing substernal chest pain for the last three days. He denies shortness of breath, palpitations, or lightheadedness. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, asthma, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include metformin and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.96 F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry is 98% on room air. Physical examination is unremarkable. The cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. ECG is shown below. Cardiac troponin levels are elevated. The patient is provided with aspirin, clopidogrel, and heparin, and the cardiac catheterization lab is activated. Which additional treatments are most appropriate to administer to this patient during hospitalization?


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chest pain and ECG findings consistent with acute myocardial infarction (hyperacute anteroseptal MI). Beta-blockers are often used to manage myocardial infarction to reduce myocardial oxygen demand by reducing AV nodal conductivity, slowing the heart rate, and reducing afterload. Administration of beta-blockers in this setting has been shown to reduce short-term morbidity and improve long-term survival.    

Beta-blockers get divided into selective (β1 blockers) and non-selective beta blockers. Cardioselective beta-blockers (β1) are safe to use in patients with underlying obstructive lung disease (e.g. asthma and chronic obstructive lung disease) due to the lack of β1 receptors in the lung.



Option Analysis

❌ Sotalol:
Incorrect:  Sotalol, a class III antiarrhythmic, is often used to manage atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, and ventricular tachycardia. It is not indicated for use in patients with recent myocardial infarction and normal sinus rhythm.
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Nonselective beta-blockers can precipitate bronchospasm in patients with underlying obstructive lung disease (e.g. asthma and chronic obstructive lung disease). 
✅ Metoprolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ibutilide:
Incorrect: Ibutilide is a class III antiarrhythmic used to manage atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter. It can prolong the QT interval and precipitate torsades de pointes. 
❌ Flecainide:
Incorrect: Flecainide is a class IC antiarrhythmic used in managing supraventricular tachycardias. It is not typically administered following the development of myocardial infarction.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after a syncopal episode while seated at church. She does not report chest pain, nausea, vomiting, seizures, or confusion. She regained consciousness a few minutes after the episode. Her past medical history includes chronic kidney disease, cluster headaches, and allergic rhinitis, for which she uses over-the-counter nasal decongestants as needed. She has recently been prescribed a new prophylactic treatment for her cluster headaches. She drinks 4-5 beers daily. She does not smoke or use recreational drugs. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 105/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 96%. ECG is shown below. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the medication responsible for this patient’s condition?
 
 By Jer5150 - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0 Reproduced from Wikipedia

choices.text: Beta blockade and inhibition of sympathetic activity
Enhanced vagal tone suppressing AV nodal conduction
Reversible inhibition of COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes

questions.solution:
This patient presents with syncope and ECG findings indicative of 2nd-degree heart block in the recent initiation of medication for cluster headache prophylaxis.
 

Verapamil is indicated as a preventive treatment for cluster headaches. Toxicity can occur due to medication overdose either secondary to intentional intake or reduced clearance from hepatic or renal insufficiency. Verapamil blocks the L-type calcium channel in the pacemaker tissue of the heart. Administration of verapamil results in prolongation of the effective refractory period of the AV node and delays depolarization of the SA node. This manifests as prolongation of the PR interval on the ECG and can progress to heart block in susceptible patients.
 

Adverse effects of class IV antiarrhythmics include constipation, hyperprolactinemia, flushing, and peripheral edema. Peripheral vasodilatory effects are more commonly encountered with dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Beta blockade and inhibition of sympathetic activity:
Incorrect: Beta blockers can inhibit adrenergic mediated repolarization of pacemaker cells, and as a result, cause prolongation of the PR interval and heart block. Beta-blockers like propranolol are used in the preventive treatment of migraine headaches but are ineffective in treating cluster headaches. Hence propranolol is unlikely to cause this patient’s syncopal episode.  
❌ Enhanced vagal tone suppressing AV nodal conduction:
Incorrect: Digoxin can cause heart block via its vagomimetic actions and suppression of AV nodal conduction. This patient was prescribed a prophylactic medication for cluster headaches.  
✅ Blockade of long-acting calcium channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Reversible inhibition of COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes:
Incorrect: NSAIDs like indomethacin are effective for treating tension and migraine headaches. They are not used in the preventive treatment of cluster headaches and do not cause prolongation of the PR interval.  
❌ Selective agonist to serotonin receptors:
Incorrect: Triptans are used for the abortive treatment of acute cluster headache episodes. They are not used to prevent cluster episodes and do not affect the PR interval.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a witnessed cardiac arrest. The patient developed pulseless ventricular tachycardia in the field and was shocked once with an AED device. Upon arrival, CPR is ongoing, intravenous access is obtained, an airway is established, one milligram of epinephrine is administered intravenously, and the patient is shocked an additional two times due to persistent ventricular tachycardia. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 87/60 mmHg, and pulse is 152/min. Which of the following agents is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department after a witnessed cardiac arrest and is given several rounds of CPR, shocks, and epinephrine to treat pulseless ventricular tachycardia. Based on advanced cardiac life support algorithms, the next best step in managing this patient’s condition is the administration of intravenous amiodarone. 

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic agent considered a first-line agent in treating pulseless ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation unresponsive to CPR, defibrillation, and epinephrine. In addition, sotalol can be used to treat ventricular tachycardia. However, sotalol is not considered a first-line agent due to its excessive ꞵ-blocking effects.

Apart from these agents, other class III antiarrhythmic agents, such as ibutilide or dofetilide, can also be used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia.

Finally, class III antiarrhythmic agents (notably amiodarone and sotalol) can also be used in treating supraventricular tachycardias, given their ꞵ-blocking effects.   

Option Analysis

✅ Amiodarone:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Diltiazem :
Incorrect: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker that is not routinely used for treating ventricular tachycardia and is not included in ACLS algorithms. It is primarily used as a rate control agent for supraventricular tachycardias.  
❌ Flecainide :
Incorrect: Flecainide is a class IC antiarrhythmic agent that can be used for ventricular tachycardia. However, it should not be used as a first-line agent.  
❌ Sotalol:
Incorrect: Sotalol is a class III antiarrhythmic agent that can be used to treat ventricular tachycardia. However, it is not included as a first-line agent in ACLS algorithms.  
❌ Esmolol:
Incorrect: Esmolol is a class II antiarrhythmic agent used for rapid blood pressure management in intracranial hemorrhage and aortic dissection. However, it is not used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with crushing substernal chest pain that started one hour prior to arrival. The patient’s initial electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, for which he is taken to the cardiac catheterization lab for stent placement. Shortly thereafter, his telemetry monitor alarms and a stat electrocardiogram is obtained and shown below. Of the following medications, which is the most effective treatment for this patient’s clinical condition? 



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a wide complex tachycardia, which is consistent with ventricular tachycardia, after having an acute inferior myocardial infarction with stent placement. The most appropriate medication to treat this patient’s condition is a class IB antiarrhythmic, such as lidocaine or mexiletine.        

Class IB antiarrhythmics are weak sodium channel blockers and preferentially affect ischemic or depolarized purkinje and ventricular tissue. This property makes them excellent agents for use in ventricular arrhythmias in the peri-myocardial infarction period. These medications effectively block sodium channels in depolarized tissues or inactivated sodium channels, which are highly abundant in ischemic cardiac tissue.   

Option Analysis

✅ Mexiletine :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Propafenone:
Incorrect: Propafenone is a class IC antiarrhythmic medication that has no effect on the effective refractory period in Purkinje and ventricular tissue. As a result, this medication would not be effective in treating this patient’s ventricular tachycardia. 
❌ Procainamide:
Incorrect: Procainamide is a class IA antiarrhythmic medication that has utility in treating ventricular tachycardia. However, it is not the most effective agent in this situation due to its lack of selectivity towards ischemic cardiac tissue. Mexiletine would be a more effective treatment option.       
❌ Diltiazem:
Incorrect: Diltiazem is a class IV antiarrhythmic medication used for rate control for supraventricular tachycardias. It is not used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia. 
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol is a class II antiarrhythmic medication, which, like diltiazem, is used for rate control for supraventricular tachycardias. In contrast, it is not used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset palpitations. She was out walking her dog when she suddenly felt light-headed and dizzy. Past medical history is unremarkable and she does not take any medications daily. The patient does not drink alcohol or use illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 142/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/72 mmHg. Physical examination is grossly unremarkable. Electrocardiogram demonstrates atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response, delta waves, and wide QRS complexes. The patient is given a medication which alters the ventricular action potential as illustrated below. Which of the following medications was most likely used to terminate this patient's arrhythmia?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with palpitations and electrocardiographic findings that demonstrate atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Additionally, she has concerning features of Wolff-Parkinson White including delta waves and wide QRS complexes. She is given a medication that increases the action potential duration, increases the effective refractory period, and increases the QT interval. These properties are consistent with those of class IA antiarrhythmic medications.       

Class IA antiarrhythmic medications include quinidine, procainamide, and disopyramide. These are the only class I antiarrhythmic medications that also have class III antiarrhythmic properties, meaning that they have some potassium channel-blocking effects. Hence, these medications lead to an increased action potential duration, QT interval, and effective refractory period.   

Option Analysis

✅ Procainamide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amiodarone:
Incorrect: Amiodarone does prolong the QT interval, effective refractory period, and action potential duration by inhibiting cardiac potassium channels and hence prolonging repolarization. However, amiodarone does not significantly affect phase 0 of the action potential, which is mediated by sodium channel blockade. 
❌ Adenosine:
Incorrect: Adenosine works via blockade of the A1 adenosine receptor, which triggers an increase in potassium efflux via blockade of the AV node. In the setting of atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response and Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, blockade of the AV node can result in ventricular arrhythmias and sudden death due to increased conduction through the accessory bypass tract.  
❌ Lidocaine:
Incorrect: Lidocaine is a class IB antiarrhythmic medication, which will decrease the QT interval and action potential duration. In contrast, the above figure demonstrates an increase in action potential duration.   
❌ Flecainide:
Incorrect: Flecainide is a class IC antiarrhythmic medication, which has minimal to no effect on action potential duration. In contrast, the above figure demonstrates an increase in action potential duration.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old woman is seen by her primary care physician for a well-care visit. She has been doing well and has not seen her physician in over 2 years. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She has no shortness of breath, palpitations, dizziness, chest pain, or syncope. She has no family history of coronary artery disease. She does not use tobacco. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg, heart rate is 96 beats per minute and irregularly irregular, respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient appears comfortable. A 12-lead electrocardiogram is obtained and shows an irregular rhythm with a rapid ventricular response, without the presence of P Waves, and with variable P-R intervals. Trans-thoracic echocardiogram (TTE) shows normal left ventricular (LV) function. Laboratory tests are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Hemoglobin     13.5 g/dL   
 Thyroid-stimulating hormone     2.1 µU/mL   
 Creatinine     0.9 mg/dL   
 INR     1.0

choices.text: Start oral anticoagulant now followed by cardioversion

questions.solution:
This patient is found to have atrial fibrillation (AF) of unknown duration. She is asymptomatic, hemodynamically stable, over 70 years of age, without other risk factors for cardiovascular disease, and has normal left ventricular (LV) function; therefore, a rate control strategy using the calcium channel blocker diltiazem is preferred for managing her AF. Rate control is associated with fewer side effects and aims to reduce symptoms, improve heart function, and reduce the risk of tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy. This patient should also have risk stratification for thromboembolic and bleeding risks to help determine the need for antithrombotic therapy to prevent stroke and the risk of embolization. In addition to using calcium channel blockers, rate control can be managed with beta-blockers or digoxin.      

In contrast, rhythm control is effective at reducing symptoms, and is preferred in patients with reduced LV function, those less than 70 years of age who are more likely to maintain sinus rhythm, and patients with A-fib for less than a year. Rhythm control can be performed using electrical cardioversion, pharmacologic therapy, or catheter ablation. Pharmacological options for rhythm control include antiarrhythmics like amiodarone, flecainide, or propafenone.  

Option Analysis

✅ Start rate control with diltiazem:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Start oral anticoagulant now followed by cardioversion:
Incorrect: This patient who has atrial fibrillation of unknown duration is asymptomatic, hemodynamically stable, over 70 years of age with normal LV function. Therefore, a rate control strategy is preferred. 
❌ Schedule catheter ablation  :
Incorrect: Immediate catheter ablation without prior anticoagulation for patients with atrial fibrillation lasting more than 48 hours is contraindicated due to the elevated risk of thromboembolism. Anticoagulation for at least 3 weeks is required before considering rhythm control strategies like ablation. Additionally, this patient should be treated with a rhythm control strategy. 
❌ Perform synchronized cardioversion:
Incorrect: Synchronized cardioversion without anticoagulation in a patient with atrial fibrillation for more than 48 hours increases the risk of stroke from embolization of an atrial thrombus. Anticoagulation should be initiated first before cardioversion. Additionally, this patient should be treated with a rhythm control strategy.  
❌ Start antiarrhythmic therapy immediately:
Incorrect: Starting antiarrhythmic therapy without addressing the risk of thromboembolism is inappropriate in this patient with potential prolonged atrial fibrillation. Additionally, this patient can be treated with a rhythm control strategy.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of palpitations and shortness of breath. The symptoms started early in the morning and have been intermittent throughout the day. Past medical history is significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, chronic hypoxemic respiratory failure for which he is on 4 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula, and pulmonary hypertension. Medications include albuterol, fluticasone, salmeterol, and umeclidinium. Temperature is 36.8 ºC (98.2 ºF), pulse is 120/min and irregular, blood pressure is 132/81 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min and SpO2 is 88% of 4 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula. Electrocardiogram is obtained and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Reproduced fromWikicommons
questions.solution:
This patient with severe pulmonary disease presents with multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT), which occurs when multiple foci in the atria produce electrical impulses, causing ≥3 different P wave morphologies and an irregular rhythm. If this arrhythmia occurs with a heart rate <100/min it is called wandering atrial pacemaker (WAP). WAP and MAT are seen mostly in patients with severe underlying pulmonary disease. Treatment centers around addressing hypoxemia and treating the underlying pulmonary disease.

Among the irregular rhythms with narrow QRS complexes, atrial fibrillation will not have visible P waves, whereas multifocal atrial tachycardia will have ≥3 distinct P wave morphologies. Ventricular tachycardias, whether monomorphic or polymorphic, have complete AV dissociation (P waves may occur, but have no correlation to QRS complexes).

When regular rhythms with narrow QRS complexes (supraventricular tachycardia) are present, the P wave morphology can help determine the specific SVT. In sinus tachycardia, there is a P wave before every QRS complex, and the P waves all have the same morphology and are upright in leads I and II. Atrial tachycardias will have consistent P waves of a single morphology, but will not appear to be in sinus pattern. AV nodal reentrant tachycardia typically has P waves buried in QRS complexes, whereas AV reentrant tachycardia will have P waves following the QRS complex.  

Option Analysis

✅ Multifocal atrial tachycardia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Wandering atrial pacemaker:
Incorrect: With a wandering atrial pacemaker the heart rate is < 100/min.  
❌ Atrial fibrillation:
Incorrect: This patient’s electrocardiogram shows multiple visible P waves of different morphologies. The ECG in atrial fibrillation would not have visible P waves.  
❌ Atrial flutter with 2:1 block:
Incorrect: This electrocardiogram shows ≥3 P wave morphologies which would not be seen in atrial flutter. Sawtooth “flutter” waves are usually seen in atrial flutter (especially in inferior leads) which are not present on this electrocardiogram.  
❌ Atrial flutter with variable block:
Incorrect: This electrocardiogram shows ≥3 P wave morphologies which would not be seen in an atrial flutter with variable block.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic with complaints of fatigue, lightheadedness, and recurrent episodes of palpitations. The patient has not had chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope. He does not recall any specific situations that bring on the symptoms. There is no recent history of tick bites, rash, or fever. Past medical history is significant for hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. The patient is physically active and walks three times per week. The patient does not smoke. Temperature is 37.1°C (97.9°F), blood pressure is 128/84 mmHg, pulse is 47/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination is unremarkable. A 12-lead ECG reveals sinus bradycardia. Initial laboratory evaluation, including CBC, electrolytes, and TSH, are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, lightheadedness, and occasional episodes of tachycardia in the absence of chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope. The patient has sinus bradycardia on ECG and a normal initial laboratory evaluation. These findings are suggestive of the diagnosis tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome also known as sick sinus syndrome. The most appropriate next step to establish the diagnosis is to order a 24-hour ambulatory ECG monitor also known as a Holter monitor.

When formulating a differential diagnosis for an adult with bradycardia, several causes should be considered, including physiological sinus bradycardia, SA node block, tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome, neurally-mediated bradycardia, electrolyte imbalances, hypothyroidism, infections (e.g. Lyme carditis), structural heart disease, medication-induced bradycardia, and atrioventricular (AV) block.

Additional testing is guided by the patient's history and ECG findings. These tests may include a complete blood count (CBC), electrolytes, thyroid function tests, and Lyme serology. A 24-hour ambulatory ECG monitor (Holter monitor) may be employed to identify transient arrhythmias, periods of sinus arrest, or tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome. An echocardiogram can be used to evaluate for structural heart disease that may contribute to bradycardia. An exercise stress test can also be used to assess for chronotropic incompetence. In cases where syncope is a significant symptom, a tilt table test can be helpful to evaluate for orthostatic or vasovagal syncope. Lastly, an electrophysiology (EP) study may be considered for evaluation in cases of significant or symptomatic arrhythmias if noninvasive evaluation is inconclusive or for risk stratification when a pacemaker is considered for management.  

Option Analysis

✅ 24-hour ambulatory ECG monitor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tilt table test:
Incorrect: A tilt table test is used for assessing syncope when the initial evaluation is inconclusive and to confirm a diagnosis of vasovagal or orthostatic syncope. Vasovagal syncope is typically brought on by stress or prolonged standing and patients have prodromal symptoms, while orthostatic syncope occurs with changes in position.  
❌ Lyme serology:
Incorrect: Lyme carditis can present with bradycardia. However, it typically results in atrioventricular (AV) block, and not sinus bradycardia, preceded by a tick bite and a bull’s eye rash. The absence of these findings makes the diagnosis of Lyme carditis less likely.  
❌ Electrophysiology (EP) study:
Incorrect: An EP study is an invasive procedure, indicated for the evaluation of syncope, sudden cardiac death, wide complex tachyarrhythmia, or atrioventricular conduction disease if noninvasive evaluation is inconclusive. It is not the best next step in the evaluation of this patient.  
❌ Echocardiogram:
Incorrect: An echocardiogram is useful in identifying structural heart disease that may cause bradycardia. But 24-hour ambulatory ECG monitoring should be performed first to identify the arrhythmia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for a right hemicolectomy for colon cancer resection. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type II diabetes mellitus. Five days later, the patient experiences severe substernal chest burning accompanied by sweating. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 75/40 mmHg. There are no murmurs, and the lungs are clear for auscultation bilaterally. An ECG shows sinus bradycardia and evidence of ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Aspirin and morphine are administered. As the patient is transported for cardiac catheterization, he develops dizziness and becomes pale and  diaphoretic. Telemetry reveals sinus bradycardia and a heart rate of 29/min. Which of the following mechanisms of action for the drug that should be used in the immediate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely developed sinus bradycardia secondary to an inferior wall myocardial infarction (ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF). Atropine, a muscarinic antagonist, should be administered immediately. It is an anticholinergic agent that will counteract the enhanced vagal tone to increase heart rate and improve symptoms.  

Muscarinic antagonists are a class of medications that prevent muscarinic receptors of the parasympathetic nervous system from being stimulated by acetylcholine. Its receptors have been divided into the following subgroups:  



Option Analysis

❌ Antagonism of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors:
Incorrect: Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonists (e.g., doxazosin, tamsulosin) are effective in the management of benign prostatic hyperplasia and hypertension. These medications do not affect heart rate or cardiac contractility and therefore cannot be used to manage bradycardia.  
❌ Agonist of alpha-2 adrenergic receptors:
Incorrect: Clonidine and methyldopa are alpha-2 receptor agonists used to manage hypertension. These medications are not used to treat bradycardia.  
✅ Antagonism of muscarinic cholinergic receptors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Antagonism of nicotinic cholinergic receptors:
Incorrect: Drugs that block the nicotinic cholinergic receptors as tubocurarine are used during general anesthesia to induce paralysis.  
❌ Antagonism of histamine two receptors:
Incorrect: H2 receptor blockers (e.g. cimetidine) reduce gastric acid secretion and can alleviate symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease. However, these medications are not effective in the management of bradycardia.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with palpitations and lightheadedness. She has intermittently experienced these symptoms in the past. However, this time, the symptoms are persistent. Past medical history includes congestive heart failure, hypertension, and hyperthyroidism. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse actions are pressure is 122/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Physical examination reveals a thin, anxious woman with faint bibasilar rales heard on pulmonary auscultation. The patient’s electrocardiogram is demonstrated below. Administration of which of the following medications would be most appropriate in treating this patient’s clinical condition?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with palpitations, lightheadedness, and an electrocardiogram demonstrating atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. The electrocardiogram shows an irregularly irregular fast rhythm without identifiable p-waves. Of the medications listed, only metoprolol is indicated in the treatment of atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.

ꞵ-blocking medications have a wide range of applications in the treatment of cardiovascular disorders. The medications metoprolol and esmolol are excellent rate-controlling medications used to treat supraventricular tachycardias such as atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter. In addition, the ꞵ-blocker carvedilol is commonly used in the treatment of heart failure due to its ability to decrease myocardial oxygen consumption, which results in lower patient mortality. ꞵ-blockers, in general, are also excellent medications in hypertension management. In the acute setting, intravenous labetalol is often used to treat hypertension due to its fast onset of action.  

Option Analysis

✅ Metoprolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Timolol:
Incorrect: Timolol is not indicated in the treatment of atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. Instead, it is used in the treatment of glaucoma.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol, while possessing ꞵ-blocking effects, is not indicated in the treatment of atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response due to its pharmacokinetic profile and slow onset of action. Instead, propranolol is primarily used to treat performance anxiety, hyperthyroidism, and variceal bleeding.  
❌ Adenosine:
Incorrect: Adenosine is used in the treatment and termination of paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia.  
❌ Magnesium sulfate:
Incorrect: Magnesium sulfate is often used to treat torsade de pointes, but not atrial fibrillation.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man comes to his primary care physician to evaluate a fluttering sensation in his chest. This symptom has been present for many years. He has decided to seek medical care after a friend recently passed away from a “heart condition.” Past medical history is notable for hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, and osteoarthritis. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is shown below. The patient is started on a drug that may cause dyspepsia, gastritis, and increased bleeding risk as side effects. Which of the following best describes this drug’s mechanism of action?
 

 Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Inactivation of free and clot-associated thrombin

questions.solution:
This patient has atrial fibrillation and risk factors for thromboembolism, such as old age and a history of hypertension and peripheral vascular disease. The patient should be started on an anticoagulant for stroke prophylaxis. He was most likely started on a direct thrombin inhibitor, which can cause gastritis, dyspepsia, and increased bleeding risk as side effects.

Direct thrombin inhibitors can be administered intravenously (e.g., bivalirudin, lepirudin, argatroban), orally (e.g., dabigatran), or subcutaneously (e.g. desirudin). They are not as frequently used as heparin. However, they can be a second-line medication in patients with deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. They can also be used for stroke prophylaxis in patients with atrial fibrillation and in combination with antiplatelet agents to prevent clot formation in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention. Moreover, direct thrombin inhibitors are beneficial when heparin causes heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, and the patient needs to be switched to an alternative anticoagulant.

In terms of toxicity, direct thrombin inhibitors are associated with hypersensitivity reactions, gastrointestinal symptoms such as dyspepsia and gastritis, and increased bleeding risk in the setting of an overdose.  

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of γ-carboxylation of clotting factors:
Incorrect: Warfarin is an anticoagulant that inhibits γ-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX; and X proteins C and S. Warfarin can cause transient protein C and S deficiency, resulting in short-term hypercoagulability. Hence, an alternative anticoagulant (e.g. heparin) should be started before bridging to warfarin.  
❌ Activation of antithrombin III  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes heparin’s mechanism of action. Heparin can cause an increased risk of bleeding, osteoporosis, and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. However, the medication would not typically cause dyspepsia or gastritis.  
❌ Blockade of platelet P2Y12 receptors:
Incorrect: ADP receptor inhibitors, such as clopidogrel and prasugrel, work via this mechanism of action. The medications cause increased bleeding risk and gastrointestinal irritation. However, anticoagulants (e.g., heparin, direct thrombin inhibitors, factor Xa inhibitors) are more effective than antiplatelet agents in preventing thromboembolic events in patients with atrial fibrillation.  
❌ Direct inhibition of factor Xa:
Incorrect: Direct factor Xa inhibitors, such as apixaban and rivaroxaban, can be used for thromboembolism prophylaxis in patients with atrial fibrillation. While these medications increase bleeding risk, they do not typically cause gastritis or dyspepsia.  
✅ Inactivation of free and clot-associated thrombin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic to evaluate intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness since last night. He does not report syncope, chest pain, nausea, or vomiting. His past medical history includes asthma and GERD. Current medications include inhaled glucocorticoids and ranitidine. He drinks 4-5 beers and 4 cups of coffee daily. He does not smoke or use recreational drugs. His father died at the age of 50 due to a cardiac condition. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 96%. Cardiopulmonary auscultation is otherwise unremarkable. Lead II telemetry is shown below. Vagal maneuvers are trialed, and IV adenosine is administered without termination of the arrhythmia. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) as evidenced by both symptoms and ECG findings that include rapid, narrow, complex, regular tachycardia without discernable p-waves.

Verapamil and diltiazem are treatment options for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia when refractory to vagal maneuvers or adenosine.
 


Pacemaker tissue depends on calcium currents to generate action potentials. Verapamil and diltiazem inhibit L-type calcium channels in pacemaker tissue, prolonging the effective refractory period of the AV node and slowing down the transmission of the electrical impulse through the AV node. Therefore, they are useful in treating supraventricular tachyarrhythmias dependent on conduction through the AV node.
 

In the presence of unstable vital signs, direct cardioversion is the preferred treatment of choice for PSVT.  The other indications for class IV antiarrhythmics include rate control for atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter, management of chronic stable angina, as well as multifocal atrial tachycardia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Lidocaine:
Incorrect: Lidocaine is a class Ib antiarrhythmic agent that blocks inactivated sodium channels. It is indicated in treating ventricular arrhythmias (wide complex), particularly those originating from ischemic tissue.  
✅ Diltiazem:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Direct cardioversion:
Incorrect: Direct cardioversion is indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients (hypotension, loss of consciousness, heart failure, altered mental status). In this patient with stable vital signs, an AV nodal blocking agent such as diltiazem would be the best next step in management.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: In this patient with a history of asthma, administering nonselective beta-blockers could induce bronchospasm.  
❌ Ibutilide:
Incorrect: Ibutilide is a class III antiarrhythmic and a beta blocker. It is no longer recommended for the treatment of atrial flutter and fibrillation. It is not a treatment of choice for PSVT.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of confusion. He is accompanied by his spouse, who states that he has appeared confused and lethargic since this morning. Since then, he has had three episodes of vomiting. He has also reported ýellow tinted vision. His medical history includes chronic systolic heart failure and hypertension. His current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, spironolactone, digoxin and metoprolol.  He was hospitalized two days ago for an episode of atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response, which was treated with metoprolol and an amiodarone drip. He does not smoke or use recreational drugs. He consumes 2-3 beers on the weekends. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 95/85 mmHg. Mucous membranes are moist. Fingerstick glucose is 110 mg/dL. ECG is shown below. Which of the following additional findings would you expect to find in the laboratory evaluation of this patient?
 
 By Jer5150 - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0,  Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents gastrointestinal symptoms, vision abnormalities, altered mental status, and a history of digoxin intake. These findings, coupled with recent amiodarone administration, are consistent with acute digoxin toxicity. Medications like amiodarone, verapamil, quinidine, and spironolactone can induce digoxin toxicity by reducing the renal filtration of digoxin.
 

Arrhythmias are the most dangerous manifestation of acute digoxin toxicity. They may include atrial tachycardia with AV block, premature ventricular contractions, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, complete heart block, Mobitz type II heart block, symptomatic bradycardia, and asystole.
 

Electrolyte imbalances often accompany digitalis toxicity as this medication inhibits the sodium potassium channel of cardiac myocytes. Hyperkalemia is the most commonly encountered electrolyte abnormality and is a significant predictor of mortality.

Acute management of digitalis toxicity involves the administration of antibody fragments that bind to and eliminate digoxin. If antibody fragments are not immediately available, atropine or temporary transvenous pacing can be used to treat symptomatic bradycardia.

Due to its vagomimetic actions, digoxin is considered an option for rate control in atrial arrhythmias.
