However, it is not the first line agent for atrial arrhythmias owing to its low therapeutic window and adverse cardiac effects.  Digoxin is an effective treatment of atrial fibrillation in patients with concomitant heart failure or hypotension due to its added inotropic actions and its negative chronotropic effects.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hypokalemia:
Incorrect: Hypokalemia is a concern in the setting of chronic digoxin toxicity. Acute digitalis toxicity is more commonly associated with hyperkalemia due to sodium-potassium channel blockade.  
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia can manifest with neuroglycopenic symptoms (confusion, altered mental status, dizziness) and autonomic symptoms (tremors, palpitations, diaphoresis). Complete heart block is not commonly encountered. Normal fingerstick glucose makes hypoglycemia unlikely.  
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect: Symptoms of hyponatremia include headache, confusion, malaise, coma, and seizures. Complete heart block, visual abnormalities, and gastrointestinal disturbances indicate digitalis toxicity.  
✅ Hyperkalemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Wide anion metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: A wide anion gap metabolic acidosis is encountered with ethylene glycol, ethanol, and salicylate poisoning. Although these toxidromes can present with gastrointestinal and neurologic disturbances, complete heart block makes digoxin toxicity a more likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of cough, recurrent palpitations, and wheezing for the past four days. The patient reports associated low-grade fevers and states that she was recently visiting her grandchildren who are also ill. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, coronary artery disease, and emphysema for which she is on 2 liters of continuous supplemental oxygen. She reports increasing her oxygen to 3L over the past 24 hours. The patient smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day and drinks alcohol socially. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 132/min and irregular, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 110/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on 3 L nasal cannula. Neck pulses are normal. Cardiopulmonary exam reveals wheezing throughout the lung fields, coughing, and rales over the left lung base. Which of the following tachyarrhythmias is most likely to be seen on electrocardiogram (ECG)?

choices.text: Atrial flutter with rapid ventricular response

questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical findings consistent with a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation, and he has an irregular tachycardic pulse associated with recurrent palpitations. Multifocal atrial tachycardia is the most likely diagnosis. It is commonly seen in patients with pulmonary conditions such as COPD/emphysema or in patients with hypomagnesemia and theophylline use. The ECG is characterized by changing the morphology of the P waves and a variable PR interval leading to an irregular pulse and a heart rate greater than 100 bpm. Management is based on treating the underlying condition or administering intravenous magnesium.

Patients presenting with distinct types of supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs) (defined as narrow complex tachycardias) tend to exhibit similar symptoms including lightheadedness, dizziness, syncope, palpitations and occasionally exercise intolerance. Physical examination may reveal clues to the type of SVT (e.g., regular pulse or irregular pulse) or bounding neck pulses that can occur in patients with AVNRT. Whether patients have a regular or irregular pulse rate can help narrow down the type of Supraventricular arrhythmia. Conditions where patients have a regular pulse include sinus tachycardia, focal atrial tachycardia, typical AVNRT, orthodromic AVRT, and atrial flutter with RVR. In contrast, SVT’s where patients have an irregular pulse include atrial fibrillation and multifocal atrial tachycardia. An electrocardiogram is necessary to diagnose the specific type of arrhythmia.

Option Analysis

✅ Multifocal atrial tachycardia:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Sinus tachycardia:
Incorrect: Sinus tachycardia would present with a regular pulse, not an irregular pulse as seen in this patient. This patient with emphysema and an irregular pulse who presents with recurrent palpitations most likely has multifocal atrial tachycardia. 
❌ Typical AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT):
Incorrect: Typical AV nodal reentrant tachycardia is a regular supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) that results from a reentry circuit within the AV node and perinodal tissue.  Patients present with a regular pulse. This patient with emphysema who presents with recurrent palpitations and has an irregular pulse at 132/min most likely has multifocal atrial tachycardia. 
❌ Atrial tachycardia:
Incorrect: Atrial tachycardia (AT) is a regular atrial rhythm at a constant rate of >100 beats per minute that originates outside the sinus node. This patient with emphysema who presents with recurrent palpitations and has an irregular pulse at 132/min most likely has multifocal atrial tachycardia. 
❌ Atrial flutter with rapid ventricular response:
Incorrect: Atrial flutter with rapid ventricular response refers to a type of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) that presents with a “saw tooth” pattern found in the inferior leads; patients present with a regular pulse of around 150 beats/min. This patient with emphysema who presents with recurrent palpitations and has an irregular pulse at 132/min most likely has multifocal atrial tachycardia.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of the acute onset of palpitations and lightheadedness. The patient was sitting at her desk when the symptoms began abruptly. She has otherwise been in her usual state of health. She has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 170/min and regular, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 120/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is well appearing but anxious. Cardiopulmonary examination is otherwise unremarkable. Lead II of the patient’s electrocardiogram (ECG) is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 

Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient, without a significant past medical history, presents with the abrupt onset of palpitations and lightheadedness. She is stable and has ECG findings of regular, tachycardic, narrow QRS complexes with absent P-waves. She most likely has typical AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), a type of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Patients with stable AVNRT should be treated in a stepwise fashion. First, with vagal maneuvers such as valsalva where patients bear down as if attempting to have a bowel movement, carotid massage, or ice baths.

If these maneuvers fail to convert AVNRT to normal sinus rhythm then, the next step is to administer adenosine, which will typically convert the patient to normal sinus rhythm.  If adenosine does not convert the rhythm, then rate-controlling agents such as metoprolol, calcium channel blockers, or amiodarone can be given. Catheter-directed ablation may also be performed.

All unstable patients with SVT, such as those with altered mental status, hypotension, or signs of such, should have immediate synchronized cardioversion. Patients with arrhythmias like focal atrial tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, and atrial flutter should be treated with rate-controlling agents like beta blockers or calcium channel blockers, and patients with atrial fibrillation/flutter should be considered for anti-coagulation given the risk of thromboembolic disease. Patients with refractory arrhythmias should be considered for catheter ablation. Notably, patients with multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) are often difficult to rate control, and treatment directed at treating the underlying disease along with magnesium sulfate is typically used. With sinus tachycardia, patients should be assessed for physiologic causes like anxiety, pain, and exercise or pathologic causes, like infection, hypovolemia, and anemia. Treatment should be aimed at correcting the pathologic etiology if present (e.g., fluid administration or blood product administration for dehydration).

Option Analysis

✅ Vagal maneuvers:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Defibrillation:
Incorrect: Defibrillation is performed for pulseless ventricular tachycardia, torsade de pointe, or ventricular fibrillation. This patient presents with stable supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), requiring vagal maneuvers or adenosine.  
❌ Adenosine:
Incorrect: Adenosine is indicated in the management of patients with stable supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) if vagal maneuvers do not improve symptoms and convert the rhythm to normal sinus rhythm. Vagal maneuvers should be attempted for this stable patient before proceeding to adenosine.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol can be utilized to treat patients with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) whose symptoms and rhythm are refractory to conversion to normal sinus rhythm with vagal maneuvers and adenosine. Vagal maneuvers and adenosine administration should be attempted first for this stable patient before proceeding to metoprolol administration. 
❌ Synchronized cardioversion:
Incorrect: Synchronized cardioversion is indicated for patients with unstable supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) (e.g., SVT accompanied by hypotension, altered mental status, or shock). This patient with stable SVT should first be managed with vagal maneuvers.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after suddenly collapsing while out for a walk. Upon arrival, the patient is lightheaded and short of breath. An electrocardiogram obtained by emergency medical services en route is demonstrated below. The patient is given a medication that markedly prolongs the cardiac action potential repolarization. Which of the following best describes this medication's primary mechanism of action?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Decrease in SA and AV nodal activity
Selective blockade of fast sodium channels
Increase in potassium efflux via blockade of the AV node

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a syncopal episode with ventricular tachycardia. She is given a medication that markedly prolongs repolarization of the ventricular action potential, which is consistent with the mechanism of action of class III antiarrhythmic medications.

Class III antiarrhythmic medications function primarily via blockade of potassium rectifier currents, which results in a prolonged phase three and marked prolongation of the ventricular action potential (AP) duration. An increase in the AP duration results in an increased effective refractory period, QT interval, and subsequent ability of the heart to react to reentrant tachycardias.

In addition to this primary mechanism, class III medications such as amiodarone and dronedarone also have some class I, II, and IV effects via the blockade of sodium channels, ꞵ-receptors, and calcium channels, respectively. Notably, amiodarone has the most potent effects, effectively treating arrhythmias.

Additional medications in this class include ibutilide, dofetilide, and sotalol.    

Option Analysis

✅ Blockade of potassium rectifier currents:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decrease in SA and AV nodal activity:
Incorrect: ꞵ-blockers work via selective ꞵ-receptor blockade, decreasing intracellular cAMP and Ca2+ currents. These effects ultimately decrease the slope of phase four of the cardiac action potential.  
❌ Selective blockade of fast sodium channels:
Incorrect: Blockade of fast sodium channels is the mechanism of action of class I antiarrhythmic medications.  
❌ Blockade of voltage-dependent calcium channels:
Incorrect: Class IV antiarrhythmic medications work by inhibiting voltage-dependent calcium channels, decreasing conduction velocity, increasing the PR interval, and increasing the effective refractory period.  
❌ Increase in potassium efflux via blockade of the AV node:
Incorrect: Adenosine works via blockade of A1 adenosine receptors, which leads to increased potassium efflux and blocking of the AV note. This medication is not used to treat ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with lightheadedness and dizziness. He feels his heart is “in that funny rhythm again.” Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 152/87 mmHg, and pulse is 138/min. An electrocardiogram from triage demonstrates atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. The patient is given a medication that acts primarily on the phase of the cardiac action potential as designated in the figure below. Which medications were most likely used to treat this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptomatic atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. The patient is administered a medication that works on phase three of the cardiac action potential, consistent with the mechanism of action of class III antiarrhythmic medications. Of the medications listed, only ibutilide has class III activity.  

Class III antiarrhythmic medications function primarily via the blockade of potassium rectifier currents and exert the most significant effect on phase three of the cardiac action potential. The blocking of potassium rectifier currents by these medications results in an increased effective refractory period, QT interval, and ability of the heart to react to reentrant tachycardia. Notable medications in this class include amiodarone, ibutilide, dofetilide, and sotalol.   

Option Analysis

✅ Ibutilide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Flecainide :
Incorrect: Flecainide is a class IC antiarrhythmic that works via strong sodium channel blockade, which decreases the slope of phase 0. It does not affect phase three of the cardiac action potential. 
❌ Propafenone:
Incorrect: Propafenone, like flecainide, is a class IC antiarrhythmic that works via strong sodium channel blockade, which results in a decrease in the slope of phase 0. It does not have a meaningful effect on phase 3 of the cardiac action potential. 
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol is a class II medication that exerts its effects via ꞵ-receptor blockade. It does not affect phase three of the cardiac action potential. 
❌ Ivabradine:
Incorrect: Ivabradine prolongs phase four of slow depolarization by inhibiting the “funny” sodium channel. The medication does not affect phase three of the cardiac action potential.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. According to the patient’s caretaker, he was found at the foot of his bed this morning. Past medical history is notable for coronary artery disease, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), the pulse is 202/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 100/72 mmHg. Physical examination is significant for a pale man with profuse diaphoresis and rales bilaterally. The results of the initial electrocardiogram are shown below. He is given a medication that functions by blocking potassium rectifier currents. Which of the following graphs best represents the desired effects on the cardiac action potential after administering this medication? 
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This ill-appearing patient in respiratory distress presents with altered mental status. The electrocardiogram demonstrates wide-complex tachycardia, consistent with ventricular tachycardia. He was prescribed a class three antiarrhythmic medication, blocking potassium rectifiers. Choice A illustrates this medication's effects on the cardiac action potential. 

Class III antiarrhythmics block potassium rectifier currents, prolonging phase three of the action potential (AP) and AP duration. An increase in AP duration increases the effective refractory period it takes for the heart to reach phase four for another depolarization. Ultimately, these changes manifest with a prolonged QT interval on an electrocardiogram. 

In addition to this primary mechanism, class III medications also have some class I, II, and IV effects via the blockade of sodium channels, ꞵ-receptors, and calcium channels, respectively. Specifically, amiodarone and dronedarone have all of these properties, resulting in a mild decrease in the slope of phase zero, a decrease in the height of phase two, and a decrease in the slope of phase four.    

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Procainamide is a class IA antiarrhythmic drug used to treat cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation. It depresses phase 0 and increases the duration of the action potential.  
❌ :
Incorrect: Mexiletine is a class Ib sodium channel blocker. The medication depresses phase 0 and shortens repolarization, thereby decreasing the duration of the action potential.  
❌ :
Incorrect: Flecainide and propafenone are class Ic sodium channel blockers that function by depressing phase 0. These medications have minimal effect on cardiac repolarization. As a result, they do not impact action potential duration. 
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ :
Incorrect: This graph demonstrates the effects of a class IV antiarrhythmic agent, such as diltiazem. These effects are mediated by calcium channel blockade, not sodium.

questions.text: Medication A is under study for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias. Based on use in animal models, it is found that this medication increases action potential duration and effective refractory period with a subsequent increase in QT interval. The medication is found to increase liver function enzymes in animal models. Pre-administration (black) and post-administration (red) cardiac action potentials are demonstrated below. Which of the following best describes this medication's class(es) of antiarrhythmic properties?

choices.text: Classes I, II, III, and IV

questions.solution:
The medication increases the cardiac action potential (AP) duration, effective refractory period, and QT interval. It is also found to cause an increase in liver function tests. Based on the figure, the medication decreases the slope of phase 0, reduces the height of phase 2, prolongs phase 3, and decreases the slope of phase 4. Both medications possess class I, II, and IV activity. 

Like other class III antiarrhythmics, Amiodarone and dronedarone block potassium rectifier currents, resulting in prolongation of phase 3 and the AP duration, increase in the effective refractory period, and prolongation of the QT interval on an electrocardiogram.  

In addition to these class III effects, the drugs’ class I effects result in sodium channel blockade, class II effects result in ꞵ-blockade, and class IV effects result in decreased conduction velocity. These properties ultimately manifest with the changes observed in the figure above and make amiodarone and potent dronedarone antiarrhythmics used in treating both supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias. 

In contrast, other class III antiarrhythmics (e.g., dofetilide, ibutilide) only demonstrate prolongation of phase 3.    

Option Analysis

❌ Class I :
Incorrect: Class I medications are predominantly sodium channel blockers, with class Ia exhibiting some potassium channel blocking effects. These medications do not have calcium channel-blocking effects and hence would not affect phase two of the cardiac action potential. 
❌ Class II :
Incorrect: Class II medications such as metoprolol will predominantly affect pacemaker cells by decreasing the slope of phase 4 of the cardiac action potential. In contrast, this medication described in the question stem also involves phases zero, two, and three. 
❌ Class III :
Incorrect: Typical class III medications such as dofetilide and ibutilide have potassium channel-blocking effects but do not have notable sodium or calcium channel-blocking effects. As a result, class III medications do not typically affect phases zero and two of the cardiac action potential. 
❌ Class II, III :
Incorrect: Sotalol is generally classified as a class III antiarrhythmic medication, although it has some class two effects. It does not have significant calcium channel-blocking effects and would not affect phase two of the cardiac action potential. 
✅ Classes I, II, III, and IV:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old previously healthy man is brought to the emergency department after experiencing chest pain that radiates down the left arm. Emergency medical services provide the patient with supplemental oxygen, aspirin, and sublingual nitroglycerin. On arrival, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 136/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 100/72 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 93% on 2L nasal cannula. The patient's initial electrocardiogram is shown below. He is subsequently started on medication with moderate sodium channel blockade. Which of the following best illustrates the effect this medication will have on the cardiac action potential?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response in the setting of a clinical history concerning acute coronary syndrome. He is subsequently given medication with a moderate effect on sodium channel blockade, which is consistent with the mechanism of action of class IA antiarrhythmic medications. Among the answer choices, choice A best characterizes the effects these medications have on the cardiac action potential.        

Only sodium channel blockers (class I antiarrhythmics) will affect the duration of the action potential (AP) by modulating phase 0 (as illustrated in the figure). Class Ia drugs block fast-acting sodium channels, slowing Phase 0 upswing, and increasing the AP duration. In addition, class IA drugs have some potassium channel blockade, resulting in further AP and refractory period prolongation. Class IB drugs shorten the AP and effective refractory period. Class IC drugs dramatically slow phase 0, but do not increase the AP duration.    

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ :
Incorrect: Mexiletine is a class Ib sodium channel blocker that functions by mildly depressing phase 0 and shortening repolarization, thereby decreasing the duration of the action potential. Mexiletine has weak (not moderate) sodium channel blockade properties.  
❌ :
Incorrect: Flecainide and propafenone are class Ic sodium channel blockers that function by depressing phase 0 with minimal effects on repolarization. Therefore, these medications do not have an effect on action potential duration. Class Ic medications have strong (not moderate) sodium channel blockade properties. 
❌ :
Incorrect: Sotalol is a non-selective adrenergic ꞵ-receptor blocker. It can also block potassium channels and can be used as a class III antiarrhythmic agent, with its main effects on phases 3 and 4. Sotalol does not cause sodium channel blockade. 
❌ :
Incorrect: This graph demonstrates the effects of a class IV antiarrhythmic agent such as diltiazem. These effects are mediated by calcium channel blockade, not sodium.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and obesity presents to the clinic for evaluation of palpitations, shortness of breath, and fatigue for two days. She notes the palpitations occur mostly at rest and are associated with lightheadedness. She has never experienced this before. She does not have chest pain, syncope, or exertional limitations. She takes lisinopril and metformin but reports poor adherence to her medications. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 148/88 mm Hg, heart rate is 92 beats per minute and irregularly irregular, respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. BMI is 32 kg/m2. The rest of the Cardiovascular examination reveals no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. electrocardiogram shows atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is young and presents with symptomatic new onset stable atrial fibrillation, therefore elective electrical cardioversion should be attempted to try to establish normal sinus rhythm. Before cardioversion, the patient should have a transesophageal echocardiogram to determine if a left atrial thrombus is present. If a thrombus is present and there are no contraindications to anticoagulation, then anticoagulation is necessary before cardioversion. If there is no atrial thrombus then cardioversion without anticoagulation can be attempted.       

In patients diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, history should focus on identifying risk factors for atrial fibrillation like hypertension, diabetes, obesity, and obstructive sleep apnea. Physical exams may reveal an irregular pulse. A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) should be ordered to confirm AF. Findings on ECG consistent with AF include an irregular rhythm, the absence of P waves, and variable R-R intervals.        

Once AF is confirmed with ECG, a transesophageal echocardiogram should be performed to determine if a left atrial thrombus is present before cardioversion to determine the need for anticoagulation before cardioversion. Transthoracic echo can be performed in patients with long-standing AF who are not going to undergo cardioversion to determine left atrial size and left ventricular function. Laboratory tests, including thyroid function and electrolyte levels, should be ordered to detect reversible causes of AF. Additional tests such as ambulatory monitoring may be used for paroxysmal AF. The CHA2DS2-VASc score should be calculated to assess stroke risk, and the HAS-BLED score should be calculated to determine bleeding risk in all patients to guide decision-making regarding anticoagulation.   

Option Analysis

❌ Coronary angiography:
Incorrect: Coronary angiography is used to diagnose and manage coronary artery disease in patients with symptoms of angina or after an acute coronary event. This patient has no signs of ischemic heart disease. This patient is young and has symptomatic new onset stable atrial fibrillation. She should have a transthoracic echocardiogram to rule out the presence of a left atrial thrombus before electrical cardioversion.
✅ Transesophageal echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 24-hour Holter monitor:
Incorrect: A 24-hour Holter monitor is useful for detecting intermittent or paroxysmal arrhythmias. Atrial fibrillation has been diagnosed in this patient by electrocardiogram. She has symptomatic new-onset atrial fibrillation and should have a transesophageal echocardiogram to rule out the presence of a left atrial thrombus before an attempt at electrical cardioversion 
❌ Stress echocardiogram:
Incorrect: A stress echocardiogram is indicated to evaluate for ischemia in patients with suspected coronary artery disease. This patient has no signs of ischemic heart disease, and the ECG shows atrial fibrillation. She is young and symptomatic from new-onset atrial fibrillation. She should have a transesophageal echocardiogram to rule out the presence of a left atrial thrombus before electrical cardioversion. 
❌ Electrophysiology study:
Incorrect: An electrophysiology study is an invasive test that can map arrhythmias and guide ablation procedures. This procedure is typically reserved for complex cases of arrhythmias or refractory atrial fibrillation. It is not the first-line treatment in patients diagnosed with stable new-onset atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease and heart failure presents to the emergency department after a short episode of chest pain, palpitations, and lightheadedness. During the evaluation, his symptoms return and he becomes unresponsive. There is no pulse. His cardiac telemetry strip is shown below. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is currently in cardiac arrest, and the cardiac telemetry shows a uniform, wide QRS complex tachycardia with a rate of around 150 beats per minute. This is consistent with monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT).

VT originates from an abnormal ectopic ventricular pacemaker and is often associated with myocardial ischemia or structural heart disease. The first step in evaluating a patient with VT is performing an ABCDE assessment. In unstable patients, acute management to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation should be employed. This may include resuscitation efforts (e.g., chest compressions, defibrillation, intubation, oxygen), obtaining IV access, and placing the patient on cardiac and vital sign monitoring.

In pulseless VT, defibrillation should occur as soon as possible after initiating high-quality CPR. Antiarrhythmics, such as amiodarone or lidocaine, may be used for cases refractory to defibrillation. Additionally, reversible causes of cardiac arrest should be identified and treated. These can be remembered as the 5 H’sand T’s: Hypoxia, Hypothermia, Hypovolemia, Hydrogen ions (for acidosis), Hyper- or Hypokalemia, Toxins, cardiac Tamponade, Thrombosis (for myocardial infarction), Thrombosis again (for pulmonary embolism), and Tension pneumothorax.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Chest compressions:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Synchronized cardioversion:
Incorrect: Synchronized cardioversion is used to convert tachyarrhythmias when a pulse is present. However, the patient does not have a pulse, so high-quality CPR and defibrillation would be necessary.  
❌ Defibrillation:
Incorrect: Defibrillation would be advised for pulseless ventricular tachycardia. However, chest compressions should be initiated first while the defibrillator pads are being placed.  
❌ Magnesium sulfate administration:
Incorrect: Intravenous magnesium sulfate is a first-line treatment for torsades de pointes, a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. However, this patient has pulseless monomorphic ventricular tachycardia.  
❌ Amiodarone administration:
Incorrect: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication that is often used in the management of ventricular tachycardia. However, this patient is in cardiac arrest, and therefore high-quality CPR and defibrillation would take precedence.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by paramedics after suddenly losing consciousness in the grocery store and requiring CPR and defibrillation. A copy of the rhythm strip during resuscitation efforts is shown below. The patient’s sister reports that the patient has schizophrenia and was recently started on haloperidol. The patient had not complained of chest pain, shortness of breath, or fevers prior to the event. Which of the following ECG findings would be expected based on the history and presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presented with a sudden cardiac arrest due to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). More specifically, the waxing and waning amplitude on the cardiac rhythm strip is indicative of torsades de pointes. Torsades de pointes classically occurs in patients with acquired or congenital QT prolongation.
 

There are many potential causes of acquired QT prolongation, such as electrolyte abnormalities and medications. This patient was recently started on haloperidol, which has a known risk of QT prolongation. The mnemonic “ABCDE” can be used to help remember some of the most common medication classes associated with QT prolongation, such as antiArrhythmics, antiBiotics, anti”C”ychotics, antiDepressants, and antiEmetics.

Intravenous magnesium is the first-line treatment for torsades de pointes, and defibrillation is also used when a pulse is not present. From there, identification and management of the underlying cause (electrolyte replacement, withdrawal of the offending medication) is paramount to help normalize the QT interval and prevent recurrence.  

Option Analysis

❌ Peaked T waves:
Incorrect: Peaked T waves can be seen in severe hyperkalemia, which is a potential cause of ventricular tachycardia. However, this patient’s history suggests that this episode is related to the recent initiation of haloperidol, which is associated with torsades de pointes and QT prolongation.  
✅ Prolonged QT interval:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diffuse ST segment elevation:
Incorrect: Diffuse ST segment elevation can be seen in pericarditis. However, this patient’s lack of symptoms and history of recent haloperidol initiation does not fit with this diagnosis.  
❌ Delta waves:
Incorrect: Delta waves can be seen in patients with Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, which is associated with supraventricular tachycardia. However, this patient’s rhythm strip is consistent with polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.  
❌ Diffuse ST segment depressions:
Incorrect: Diffuse ST segment depression may be seen in conditions such as myocardial ischemia (particularly with left main coronary artery disease) or hypothermia. However, the patient’s history does not support either of these diagnoses.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the emergency department with lightheadedness and fatigue. Electrocardiogram is performed and the patient is found to be in atrial fibrillation with a heart rate of 84 beats per minute. Thirty minutes later the patient becomes lightheaded and develops chest pressure. Repeat electrocardiogram shows atrial fibrillation with a heart rate of 156 beats per minute. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), blood pressure is 78/55 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. On examination, the patient appears confused and uncomfortable. Peripheral IV access is established. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an unstable tachyarrhythmia (atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response with chest pain and hypotension) and requires immediate synchronized cardioversion.

The first step in managing patients presenting with tachycardia is to evaluate for stability via an ABCDE assessment. Initial management includes establishing IV access and providing supplemental oxygen if needed. Advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) protocols should be followed.

Unstable tachycardia is defined as tachycardia with hypotension, altered mental status, ischemic chest pain, or acute heart failure. Heart rates are generally >150 bpm. Patients who are unstable from tachycardia and who have a pulse should immediately undergo synchronized cardioversion to try and break the unstable rhythm. With synchronized cardioversion, the shock is synced to the patient’s underlying rhythm and delivered in concordance with the QRS complex to avoid precipitating ventricular fibrillation. If this patient had tachycardia and no pulse, he would likely have ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia, requiring immediate defibrillation and CPR. In patients with ventricular fibrillation, the underlying rhythm is unorganized and erratic, so the patient instead receives an untimed shock referred to as defibrillation.

In patients with stable tachycardia, treatment is directed at managing symptoms and treating the underlying etiology. Patients with AV nodal-reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) should be given IV adenosine. Patients with atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter with rapid ventricular response (pulse >110/min) who are stable can be given IV beta-blockers or IV calcium channel blockers (usually diltiazem) for rate control.  

Option Analysis

✅ Perform synchronized cardioversion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform vagal maneuver:
Incorrect: Vagal maneuvers increase parasympathetic tone and can slow AV nodal conduction in certain arrhythmias (e.g. AV nodal reentrant tachycardia). This patient has unstable tachycardia from atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response requiring electrical cardioversion.  
❌ Administer IV amiodarone:
Incorrect: IV amiodarone (usually given as a bolus followed by infusion) is frequently used for management of wide-complex tachycardias. This unstable patient has atrial fibrillation which is a narrow-complex tachycardia requiring immediate electrical cardioversion.  
❌ Administer IV metoprolol:
Incorrect: IV beta-blockers (e.g., esmolol, metoprolol) are frequently used to control heart rate in stable patients with narrow-complex tachyarrhythmias (e.g. atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response). This patient is unstable.  
❌ Administer sublingual nitroglycerin:
Incorrect: This patient’s chest discomfort is likely secondary to symptomatic atrial fibrillation rather than acute coronary syndrome. Moreover, nitroglycerin should be avoided in this patient with hypotension.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status, and chest discomfort. The patient has not had fever, cough, diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2. Temperature is 36.2°C (97.2°F), blood pressure 100/60 mmHg, pulse is palpable at 42/min, respiratory rate 22 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation 94% on 4L nasal cannula. The patient is awake but disoriented to place, time, and person and appears pale and diaphoretic. IV access is obtained, and IV fluids are initiated. An ECG is performed and is shown below. Which of the following is the best initial step in management?
   

From Wikipedia

choices.text: Admit the patient to the cardiac unit for further investigation and monitoring

questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, chest discomfort, and sinus bradycardia consistent with symptomatic bradycardia. The first step in the management of symptomatic bradycardia is to determine whether the patient is hemodynamically stable or unstable. Findings that indicate hemodynamic instability include altered mental status, hypotension, shock, ischemic chest discomfort, and heart failure. In addition to obtaining IV access and ensuring adequate oxygenation, the best initial step in the management of a hemodynamically unstable patient with symptomatic bradycardia is the administration of atropine.

Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist that competitively inhibits acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, reversing cholinergic-mediated decreases in heart rate and AV node conduction. The recommended dose for symptomatic bradycardia is 1 mg IV, which can be repeated every 3-5 minutes, for a total of 3 mg.

If atropine is ineffective or contraindicated, alternative treatments include administration of epinephrine, dopamine, and transcutaneous pacing. Once the patient is stabilized, further investigations, including monitoring in the cardiac unit, may be necessary to determine the underlying cause of the bradycardia and provide appropriate long-term management.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer atropine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer epinephrine infusion:
Incorrect: Epinephrine is a second-line agent for the management of symptomatic bradycardia in a hemodynamically unstable patient. It is indicated following failure of response to atropine or if atropine is contraindicated.  
❌ Administer amiodarone:
Incorrect: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic indicated for the management of ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia. It is not indicated in the management of bradycardia in a hemodynamically unstable patient.  
❌ Perform transcutaneous pacing:
Incorrect: Transcutaneous pacing delivers electrical impulses via cutaneous electrodes to the heart, causing electrical depolarization and subsequent cardiac contraction. It is uncomfortable for conscious patients and is not the first choice in management of unstable sinus bradycardia. It should be reserved for situations when atropine is ineffective or contraindicated.  
❌ Admit the patient to the cardiac unit for further investigation and monitoring:
Incorrect: Admission to the cardiac unit is required for further investigation; however, it is not the best initial step in management. This patient presents with altered mental status and hemodynamic instability requiring emergent stabilization.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman comes to the office because of intermittent palpitations and progressive fatigue for the past three months. The patient does not have a cough, shortness of breath, or chest pain. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include  metformin and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. She has a 20-pack-year smoking history and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Her temperature is 37.33°C (99.2°F), pulse is 120/minute and irregularly irregular, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. ECG and laboratory findings are shown below.  


 Reproduced from Flickr 

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  13.5 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  8000/mm3 
 Platelet count    230,000/mm3 
 Creatinine   1.9 g/dL 
 BUN  35 mg/dL 
 
Which of the following is the best treatment option to prevent long-term complications in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressive fatigue and palpitations, with an irregular heart rate documented on ECG consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). In addition to rate and rhythm control, long-term anticoagulation with warfarin or another oral anticoagulant (e.g. dabigatran) is indicated due to the high risk of future thromboembolism given her CHA2DS2-VASc is ≥2.  

Systemic thromboembolism and stroke are major long-term complications in patients with atrial fibrillation. Treatment with anticoagulation has been shown to reduce the annual risk of stroke by 64% compared to placebo and by 37% compared to antiplatelet therapy alone.    

Warfarin inhibits vitamin K- dependent ɣ-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X  by inhibiting the VKOR complex, thus depleting functional vitamin K reserves and reducing the synthesis of active clotting factors. In addition to AF, warfarin has been used as an adjunct to reduce the risk of systemic embolism (e.g., recurrent myocardial infarction, stroke) after myocardial infarction and prophylaxis and treatment of thromboembolic disorders (e.g., venous, pulmonary) and embolic complications arising from cardiac valve replacement.    

Warfarin therapy should be monitored to determine dose adjustments required to optimize the time in the therapeutic range (TTR). Warfarin affects the extrinsic coagulation pathway,  measured by the prothrombin time (PT) due to early depletion of factor VII. PT readings from different institutions cannot be accurately compared (due to testing kits from other companies). Therefore, the PT gets converted into a standardized value, the international normalized ratio (INR). A regular INR is ≤1.1, and while on warfarin, the general goal INR lies between 2 and 3.  



Option Analysis

❌ Salmeterol:
Incorrect: Salmeterol is a β2 adrenergic agonist that can worsen the heart rate in patients with atrial fibrillation.  
❌ Low-molecular-weight heparin:
Incorrect: Low-molecular-weight heparin is not recommended for long-term prophylactic management in patients with atrial fibrillation. Moreover, this patient should avoid it due to her renal insufficiency (creatinine >1 g/dL). Oral anticoagulants (direct thrombin inhibitors and factor Xa inhibitors) can be used when warfarin is contraindicated or not available.   
✅ Warfarin:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: Hydrochlorothiazide is an antihypertensive agent that has no role in the management of atrial fibrillation.   
❌ Tiotropium:
Incorrect: Tiotropium is an anticholinergic agent indicated in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease management.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department with intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness that began an hour ago. The patient is currently being treated for acute bronchitis with azithromycin. Past medical history is significant for squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, Parkinson disease, and major depressive disorder. The patient is receiving antiemetic therapy for severe nausea and vomiting after his first cycle of chemotherapy. EKG is shown below. Which of the following pharmacotherapeutic agents likely caused the above EKG findings?



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with torsades de pointes in the setting of conjunctive use of an antiemetic agent with a macrolide antibiotic. The patient was most likely taking ondansetron, which is a serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonist.    

5-HT3 antagonists (e.g., ondansetron, granisetron, palonosetron) are effective in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Serotonin receptors are sensitive to irritative stimuli (e.g., chemotherapy, infections, distention) that induce serotonin production in the gastrointestinal tract. Activation of 5-HT3 serotonin receptors then relays the impulses to the medullary vomiting center. One of the well-known side effects of 5-HT3 antagonists is QT interval prolongation. Patients can develop torsades de pointes (TdP, French for “twisting of points”) if they take multiple medications that cause QT interval prolongation.    

Moreover, 5-HT3 antagonists can cause side effects including headaches, constipation, and serotonin syndrome (secondary to displacement of serotonin molecules from their receptors).   

Option Analysis

✅ Serotonin receptor antagonist :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: NK-1 receptor antagonists (e.g. aprepitant) are frequently used for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, and usually combined with dexamethasone and a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. They do not cause significant QT prolongation.
❌ Muscarinic receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Antimuscarinic agents (e.g., scopolamine) can also be used for nausea and vomiting related to chemotherapy. However, they are not typically the first-line agent. Moreover, antimuscarinic agents do not cause significant QT prolongation.
❌ Histamine-2 receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: H2-receptor antagonists (e.g., cevimeline, famotidine) are used for gastroesophageal reflux disease and related disorders. They do not cause significant QT prolongation. Some H1-receptor antagonists (e.g. promethazine) can cause QT prolongation.
❌ Cannabinoid receptor agonist :
 Incorrect: Cannabinoid receptor agonists (e.g. dronabinol) can also be used for chemotherapy-induced   nausea and vomiting, as well as anorexia. However, they do not cause significant QT prolongation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office because of generalized malaise and palpitations for the past two months. He does not have chest pain, shortness of breath, or nausea. Past medical history includes hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. An echocardiogram performed last year demonstrated mild atrial dilatation and ventricular hypertrophy. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.96 F), pulse is 123/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. ECG shows an irregular rhythm with narrow complex tachycardia and no organized P waves. Pharmacological therapy with intravenous metoprolol is initiated. Which of the following effects will metoprolol administration have on the type of cardiac cell represented in the tracing below?

choices.text: Decrease the slope of phase 0 depolarization

questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic generalized malaise and palpitations suggestive of atrial fibrillation.   Metoprolol (class II antiarrhythmic) is administered to this patient for rate control. The tracing in the question stem demonstrates the action potential of cardiac pacemaker cells in cardiac slow-response tissues such as the sinoatrial (SA) and atrioventricular (AV) nodes. In pacemaker cells, class II antiarrhythmics prevent epinephrine and norepinephrine from binding to beta receptors, which indirectly decreases the number of open L-type calcium channels. Ultimately, this decreases the amount of calcium that enters the cell at the end of phase four, leading to a slower pacemaker potential. This can be observed as a decrease in the slope during phase four and a decreased heart rate.  

β-blockers also indirectly prevent the opening of L-type calcium channels at the end of phase 2 in non-pacemaker cells (e.g. cardiac myocytes). This effect decreases the amount of intracellular calcium available to the muscle fibers, weakening the force generated during systole. Beta-blockers ultimately reduce myocardial oxygen demand by reducing heart rate and contractility via these pharmacologic effects.





Option Analysis

❌ Decrease the slope of phase 0 depolarization:
Incorrect: Class I antiarrhythmic medications block sodium entry into the cell during depolarization. This effect decreases the slope of phase 0. The tracing in the question stem corresponds to the pacemaker action potential.
❌ Lowered threshold potential:
Incorrect: Threshold potential refers to the voltage required to initiate an action potential. β1 adrenergic agonism via medications or stress, as well as mechanical stretch, decreases this threshold in both fast- and slow-response cells. Na+ channel blockers (e.g. lidocaine) increase the depolarization threshold in fast-response cells, and Ca2+ channel blockers (e.g. verapamil) raise this threshold in pacemaker cells in both the SA node and AV node.
❌ Decreased excitation and contraction coupling:
Incorrect: Decreased slope of phase 4 depolarization
✅ Decreased slope of phase 4 depolarization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced refractory period:
Incorrect: Use of the β-blockers results in cardiac membrane stabilization. Conduction through the SA and AV nodes slows, and the refractory period increases via the indirect blockade of Ca2+ entry into pacemaker cells.

questions.text:
A 22 year old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of intermittent palpitations for one month. He has noticed the palpitations intermittently, particularly during intense activity. His past medical history includes generalized anxiety disorder, for which he takes fluoxetine daily. He drinks 4-5 beers daily. He does not smoke or use recreational drugs. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 96%. Heart sounds are irregular. ECG is shown below. He is initiated on warfarin with a dose adjusted to an INR between 2-2.5, and electrical cardioversion is planned following appropriate anticoagulation. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacological agent to administer for rate control?
 
Reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with persistent atrial fibrillation as evidenced by a rapid rate, irregularly irregular rhythm, and absent P waves on ECG. Management of atrial fibrillation targets both symptom management and prevention of thromboembolism. The initial management of atrial fibrillation involves a rate or rhythm control strategy.

Agents prolonging the AV node's ERP can achieve adequate rate control of calcium channel blockers like verapamil or diltiazem, which slows the phase 4 and phase 0 depolarization in pacemaker tissues by blocking the L-type calcium channels. As a result, AV conduction is markedly slowed, and re-entry through the AV node terminates, thus aborting the associated arrhythmia. Calcium channel blockers like verapamil and diltiazem can be administered to achieve rate control in hemodynamically stable patients while considering cardioversion.  

Option Analysis

❌ Quinidine:
Incorrect: Quinidine is a type of an antiarrhythmic that slows phase 0 depolarization in ventricular myocyte action potentials. Quinidine effectively reduces the incidence of recurrent atrial fibrillation but is no longer recommended for rhythm control. It is not the first-line treatment of choice for rate control in atrial fibrillation.  
❌ Digoxin:
Incorrect: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that can reduce AV nodal effective refractory period via vagomimetic action. Digoxin is typically reserved for patients with atrial fibrillation following treatment failure with the administration of a beta blocker or calcium channel blocker.  
❌ Amiodarone:
Incorrect: Amiodarone is a Class III antiarrhythmic utilized for rhythm control in patients with atrial fibrillation. Amiodarone is associated with the greatest likelihood of maintaining sinus rhythm and is effective in preventing recurrent atrial fibrillation.  
❌ Ibutilide:
Incorrect: Ibutilide is a class III antiarrhythmic effective for pharmacological cardioversion of atrial fibrillation. It is not used as a rate control strategy for atrial fibrillation.  
✅ Verapamil:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man comes to the clinic to evaluate intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness since last night. He has not had any syncopal episodes, chest pain, nausea, or vomiting. His past medical history includes cluster headaches and GERD. His current medications include triptans PRN and ranitidine PRN. He drinks 4-5 beers and 4 cups of coffee daily. He does not smoke or use recreational drugs. His paternal uncle died at age 35 due to a cardiac condition. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 175/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 96%. Heart sounds are regular. He appears alert and oriented. Lead II telemetry is shown below. He is administered a medication that blocks calcium influx and promotes potassium expulsion from pacemaker cells resulting in hyperpolarization and prolongation of the AV node refractory period. Which of the following is the most likely therapeutic agent administered to this patient?
 
Reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) as evidenced by both symptoms and ECG findings that include rapid, narrow, complex, regular tachycardia without discernable p-waves.

In hemodynamically stable patients, non-pharmacological treatment options include vagal maneuvers. If the arrhythmia persists, IV adenosine is effective in terminating the arrhythmia.

Adenosine is an antiarrhythmic medication that binds to the adenosine receptors (A1) on pacemaker cells and promotes the efflux of potassium resulting in hyperpolarization. Additionally, adenosine inhibits L-type calcium channels. Together, these effects prolong the ERP through the AV node to depress the reentrant circuit. In most cases, adenosine is effective in terminating PSVT.

Adenosine is also used for noninvasive stress testing to evaluate chronic stable angina. Since it prolongs the effective refractory period of the AV node, it carries a risk of AV nodal block. Other adverse effects include chest pain, dyspnea, flushing, bronchoconstriction, and hypotension.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Verapamil:
Incorrect: Verapamil is an AV nodal blocking agent that can be used for the treatment of PSVT following the failure of non-pharmacological methods and adenosine. Verapamil does block L-type calcium channels and slows conduction through the AV node. However, it does not induce hyperpolarization of pacemaker tissue.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a beta blocker that inhibits adrenergically mediated ectopic activity and slows conduction through the AV node.  Propranolol is not indicated in the treatment of PSVT.  
✅ Adenosine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amiodarone:
Incorrect: Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic that blocks delayed rectifier potassium channels,  inhibits myocardial calcium channels, exerts beta-adrenergic blocking properties, and blocks inactivated sodium channels.  
❌ Ivabradine:
Incorrect: Ivarbadine is indicated in the treatment of chronic heart failure and chronic stable angina. It selectively inhibits the funny sodium channel and prolongs phase 4 of SA node depolarization.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with palpitations and lightheadedness. She returned from a trip to Mexico one week ago. Two days ago, she was seen in the emergency department for evaluation of loose stools and abdominal discomfort and was discharged. Her medical history includes hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Her medications include hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril and atorvastatin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 202/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 105/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 96% Mucous membranes appear dry. Physical examination reveals hyperactive bowel sounds in all quadrants. She appears drowsy but responds to verbal commands. Laboratory investigations and ECG reveal the findings below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   130 mEq/L 
 Potassium   2.7 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   1.4 mg/dL 
 BUN/Cr  25  
 Mg  2.0  
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  12  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  40 % 
 Platelet count  400,000/mm3 
 Leukocyte count  9,000/mm3 

 By Jer5150 - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0 Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
Most cases of hypokalemia arise from gastrointestinal or renal losses. This patient presents with symptomatic hypokalemia (N:3.5-4.0 mEq/L) from a recent gastrointestinal infection and diuretic use. Hypokalemia can manifest with characteristic changes on an ECG, although these are not always apparent.
 
 By James Heilman, MD - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0,  Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
Hypokalemic changes include ST segment depression, PR interval prolongation, U waves in the lateral leads, and a decrease in the amplitude of the T wave. The appropriate treatment for such findings would be IV potassium and cessation of medications contributing to potassium losses. Patients with hypokalemia often have associated hypomagnesemia. Magnesium replacement may be warranted in most cases when potassium is refractory to replacement.

In this patient, ECG findings indicate acquired long QT syndrome due to hypokalemia induced by gastrointestinal losses and a diuretic (hydrochlorothiazide) intake.
 

Acquired long QT syndrome can result from medications (like antipsychotics, antiemetics, antiarrhythmics, antimicrobials ), electrolyte abnormalities, and bradyarrhythmias. Torsade de pointe is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that results in cyclic twisting/alteration of the QRS axis and morphology that occurs secondary to acquired or congenital torsade de pointe.
 

The treatment of choice for torsade de pointe is IV magnesium. Although the mechanism is not clearly understood, it has been postulated that magnesium acts on the myocardium by slowing the SA node impulse formation rate, prolonging conduction time. Magnesium is essential for the movement of calcium, sodium, and potassium cardiac cells and stabilizes excitable membranes.
 

Option Analysis

✅ IV Magnesium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transvenous pacing:
Incorrect: Temporary transvenous overdrive pacing is reserved for patients with torsade de pointe who do not respond to IV magnesium.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Bradycardia can exacerbate torsade de pointe and is not the treatment of choice for long QT-related torsade de pointe in hemodynamically unstable patients.  
❌ Lidocaine:
Incorrect: Lidocaine is a Class Ib antiarrhythmic that is a useful treatment for patients with ventricular arrhythmia, particularly ischemic tissue. Although Class Ib medications can be used to manage torsade de pointe, they are not first-line agents for this condition.  
❌ 3% normal saline:
Incorrect: 3% normal saline is indicated for patients with severe, symptomatic hyponatremia. This patient's altered mental status is more likely related to her underlying cardiac arrhythmia.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of the acute onset of palpitations and lightheadedness. The patient's partner states he has been under tremendous stress this past week. She reports he has had poor sleep, increased caffeine intake and heavy alcohol use throughout the week. He has a past medical history of atrial fibrillation status post ablation. The patient has a history of alcohol use disorder and smokes 1-2 cigarettes per day. He does not take any daily medication. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 76/54 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. The patient appears pale, diaphoretic and is incoherent. Cardiopulmonary exam reveals a regular brisk tachycardic pulse. Lead II of the patient’s electrocardiogram (ECG) is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with ECG findings of a regular, tachycardic rhythm with narrow QRS complexes with absent p-waves in conjunction with altered mental status and hypotension has unstable supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). He most likely has AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT). Patients with SVT who are unstable should undergo immediate synchronized cardioversion to restore normal sinus rhythm. 

Supraventricular tachycardia refers to tachyarrhythmia that originates from or above the atrioventricular node. An SVT can be physiologic due to physical exercise or emotional stress, or pathologic, which results from abnormal electrical activity outside the sinoatrial node. Based on 12-lead ECG findings, pathologic SVTs can be subdivided into SVTs with regular cardiac rhythm, like sinus tachycardia, focal atrial tachycardia, typical AVNRT, orthodromic AVRT, and atrial flutter; and SVTs with irregular cardiac rhythm, such as atrial fibrillation and multifocal atrial tachycardia. 

When a patient presents with SVT, they should undergo an ABCDE assessment to determine if they are unstable or stable. For unstable patients, such as those with altered mental status, hypotension, or signs of shock, who have a pulse, ACLS guidelines for Tachycardia with a Pulse should be followed. Patients should first have their airway, breathing, and circulation stabilized, and IV access should be obtained. Patients should be placed on continuous vital sign monitoring including blood pressure, heart rate, pulse oximetry, and cardiac rhythm monitoring. An immediate synchronized cardioversion should be performed.   

Option Analysis

✅ Synchronized cardioversion:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Defibrillation:
Incorrect: Defibrillation should be performed for pulseless ventricular tachycardia, torsade de pointe, or ventricular fibrillation. This patient presents with unstable supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), requiring synchronized cardioversion.  
❌ Adenosine :
Incorrect: Adenosine is indicated in the management of patients with stable supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). This patient presents with unstable SVT, requiring synchronized cardioversion. 
❌ Amiodarone :
Incorrect: Amiodarone can be utilized for patients with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) that is refractory to conversion to normal sinus rhythm with adenosine. 
❌ Magnesium sulfate:
Incorrect: Magnesium sulfate should be administered to all patients presenting with torsade de pointe. This patient presents with unstable supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), requiring synchronized cardioversion.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the cardiologist's office for a follow-up visit. He was recently started on an antiarrhythmic medication to prevent future episodes of atrial fibrillation. The patient has been feeling well and has no acute symptoms. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 48/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/72 mmHg. Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. An electrocardiogram is performed and demonstrates QT-interval prolongation. Which medications were most likely used to treat this patient's atrial fibrillation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bradycardia and QT-interval prolongation after being initiated on medication to treat paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The only medication listed that satisfies both of these criteria is sotalol. 

Sotalol is classically described as a class III antiarrhythmic agent with class II antiarrhythmic properties. In other words, sotalol is both a β-blocker and a K+-channel blocker. 

The medication’s significant β-adrenergic blocking abilities can result in bradycardia, whereas the class III effects result in QT-interval prolongation. Metoprolol, propranolol, and carvedilol are β-blockers like sotalol, but these medications lack sotalol's class III K+-blocking effects and hence will not prolong the QT interval.   

Option Analysis

❌ Carvedilol:
Incorrect: Carvedilol is a β-blocker used to treat congestive heart failure, left ventricular dysfunction following a heart attack, and high blood pressure. While it can be used for rate control in atrial fibrillation and can cause bradycardia, it does not cause QT interval prolongation.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol is a class II β-blocker used to manage hypertension, angina pectoris, and myocardial infarction. It does not cause QT interval prolongation.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a class II antiarrhythmic drug (β-blocker) used to treat conditions including hypertension, angina pectoris, migraines, and hypertrophic subaortic stenosis. It does not cause QT interval prolongation.  
✅ Sotalol:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Verapamil:
Incorrect: Verapamil is a class IV antiarrhythmic drug that serves as a slow calcium channel blocker. It is used to treat angina, arrhythmias, and essential hypertension.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after experiencing sudden onset of palpitations. An initial electrocardiogram demonstrates paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia at a rate of 160/min. He is given several doses of adenosine without termination of the arrhythmia. The primary physician discusses the case with the on-call electrophysiologist, who recommends administering a medication which affects the cardiac action potential in the manner designated in the figure below. Which of the following medications was most likely used to treat this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia refractory to management with adenosine. He is subsequently given a medication that exerts a strong sodium channel blockade with no effect on the duration of the action potential, which is consistent with the mechanism of action of a class IC antiarrhythmic medications. Among the answer choices, only propafone is from this medication class.        

Class I antiarrhythmics are divided into three major classes--A, B, and C. However, all of them work via sodium channel blockade. Sodium channel blockade slows the upstroke of the sodium-dependent action potential (phase 0) and subsequently prolongs the QRS interval.        

Moreover, some of the class I antiarrhythmics have an effect on potassium channels and alter the action potential duration. Group 1A prolongs the action potential duration (due to potassium channel inhibition), 1B shortens the duration (due to potassium channel activation), and 1C has no effect on action potential duration (no effect of potassium channels).        

Understanding which medications are associated with each class and their subsequent effect on the ventricular action potential is an important concept for Step 1.  



Option Analysis

✅ Propafenone :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Diltiazem:
Incorrect: Diltiazem is a class IV antiarrhythmic medication that can be used for rate control in patients with supraventricular tachycardias. However, diltiazem does not affect the ventricular cardiac action potential and would not alter the slope of the initial upstroke.  
❌ Ibutilide:
Incorrect: Ibutilide is a class III antiarrhythmic medication and does not affect phase 0 of ventricular depolarization.  
❌ Procainamide  :
Incorrect: Procainamide exhibits moderate sodium channel blockade. However, it also has some potassium channel-blocking effects, which increase the action potential duration and effective refractory period.  
❌ Lidocaine:
Incorrect: Of all the class I antiarrhythmic medications, lidocaine exhibits the weakest effect on sodium channel blockade and will also decrease the action potential duration.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department in cardiac arrest. He has no known medical history. CPR is in progress, and the cardiac monitor demonstrates polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. Defibrillation is successful, and there is return of spontaneous circulation. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 70/min, blood pressure is 100/72 mmHg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on the ventilator. His examination and laboratory studies are unremarkable, including cardiac enzymes. Echocardiography shows no significant structural heart disease. An ECG shows ST changes in V1-3 without reciprocal changes. A portion of his ECG is shown below. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
 

Wikimedia
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a sudden cardiac arrest due to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). His ECG findings (ST elevation in V1-3 with a “coved” appearance [often described as a “shark’s tail"] and negative T waves), in conjunction with an otherwise unremarkable workup, are consistent with Brugada syndrome.

Brugada syndrome is a genetic condition caused by a mutation of voltage-gated sodium channels, which impairs depolarization. Patients are at risk for developing ventricular tachyarrhythmias (VT), most commonly polymorphic VT or ventricular fibrillation.

High-risk patients (those who have experienced sudden cardiac arrest, syncope, or sustained VT), like this patient, should be considered for placement of an implantable cardiac defibrillator (ICD) to prevent sudden cardiac death. Additional measures, such as administration of certain antiarrhythmics (e.g., quinidine, amiodarone) or catheter ablation, are considered in cases with recurrent arrhythmias.

Polymorphic VT can have other causes and should be treated based on the underlying cause. The workup of polymorphic VT should be geared towards determining the underlying cause in order to guide management. In a stable patient, it includes history, physical examination, labwork, ECG, and TTE. Polymorphic VT caused by acute coronary syndrome should be treated with reperfusion therapy. If it is caused by torsade de pointes, then the treatment is IV magnesium sulfate. If a patient with polymorphic VT is found to have underlying hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, an implantable cardioverter defibrillator should be considered. Catecholamine polymorphic VT is caused by circulating catecholamines and is treated with beta-blockers.  

Option Analysis

❌ Procainamide administration:
Incorrect: Class I antiarrhythmics, such as procainamide, are contraindicated in Brugada syndrome due to their mechanism of action (sodium channel blockade).  
❌ Cardiac catheterization:
Incorrect: Cardiac catheterization would be indicated for the management of myocardial infarction. The patient’s ECG does show ST elevation in V1-3, but without reciprocal changes or a positive troponin, making these findings more consistent with Brugada syndrome.  
❌ Magnesium sulfate administration:
Incorrect: Magnesium sulfate is used in the management of torsades de pointes. However, this patient’s ECG is concerning for Brugada syndrome.  
✅ Implantable cardiac defibrillator placement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Catheter ablation:
Incorrect: Catheter ablation is not the first-line treatment for Brugada syndrome, but may be considered for cases with recurrent ventricular tachyarrhythmias.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after experiencing a syncopal episode. The patient has had several similar episodes in the last two weeks and has also been more lightheaded and fatigued than usual. The syncopal events are abrupt and are not preceded by symptoms. Past medical history is significant for ischemic cardiomyopathy with an ejection fraction of 15%, major depressive disorder, opioid use disorder, and fibromyalgia. Current medications include carvedilol, lisinopril, methadone, ondansetron, quetiapine, and sertraline. Vital signs are obtained by the nursing staff while you examine the patient. The patient appears uncomfortable. There are no cardiac murmurs on auscultation. The patient’s radial pulse is irregular and rapid. An electrocardiogram is ordered. Which of the following arrhythmias is most likely to be seen on ECG?
questions.solution:
This patient with a rapid heart rate and history of ischemic heart disease, multiple QT interval-prolonging medications, and non-prodromal syncope likely has ventricular tachycardia (VT). The patient’s pulse is irregular on physical examination, which is consistent with polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (PVT) rather than monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (MVT). Ischemic heart disease and QT-interval prolonging medications both increase the risk of developing VT. Patients with severe QT prolongation can develop torsades de pointes, a type of PVT.

In most cases, the electrocardiogram (ECG) will identify the tachyarrhythmia. In cases where the ECG is unclear or not yet obtained, history and physical examination can suggest an etiology. Patients with ischemic heart disease are more likely to develop ventricular arrhythmias such as MVT or PVT. Patients with mitral regurgitation and resultant left atrial enlargement have a higher risk of developing atrial fibrillation. Other arrhythmias such as multifocal atrial tachycardia occur mostly in patients with underlying lung disease such as COPD. Young and otherwise healthy patients are more likely to have sinus tachycardia or reentrant tachyarrhythmias such as AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) and Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome.

Pulse examination can indicate the heart rate and whether the rhythm is regular or irregular. Other physical exam findings (e.g., cardiac murmurs, abnormal lung auscultation) may suggest an underlying pathology. In addition, physical examination findings such as altered mental status or poor capillary refill suggest hemodynamic instability and the need for cardioversion or defibrillation depending on the arrhythmia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia:
Incorrect: Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia is a tachycardia with a regular rhythm. This patient has an irregular rhythm on exam and thus likely has polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.  
❌ Wandering atrial pacemaker:
Incorrect: Wandering atrial pacemaker is an irregular rhythm with 3 or more distinct P wave morphologies. It is a non-tachycardic version of multifocal atrial tachycardia.  
❌ Atrial flutter with 4:1 block:
Incorrect: Atrial flutter is classified based on the degree of the block (how many ectopic beats are conducted). A 4:1 block would present as a regular rhythm with a heart rate of approximately 75 bpm.  
❌ AV nodal reentrant tachycardia:
Incorrect: AV nodal reentrant tachycardia has a regular rhythm and normal QRS duration. This patient’s pulse is irregular.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to palpitations and shortness of breath for the past two hours. The patient has never experienced an episode like this and has no family history of heart disease. He was in his usual state of health prior to this episode. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Vital signs and ECG are obtained by nursing staff while you examine the patient. The patient appears anxious and uncomfortable. Palpation of the radial pulse reveals a regular and rapid heart rate. After reviewing the electrocardiogram you suspect AV nodal reentrant tachycardia. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on  ECG?

choices.text: QRS <120 ms and P waves buried in the QRS complexes
The absence of typical P waves and sawtooth waves in leads III and aVF
QRS <120 ms, irregular R-R intervals, and no visible P waves
Prolonged QT interval and progressive sinusoidal alterations of the QRS axis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with palpitations, shortness of breath, and tachycardia with a regular rhythm. Given that this patient is young and healthy with no prior heart disease, no recent illnesses, and he is not taking any medications, this symptomatic regular rapid heart rate most likely indicates AV nodal reentrant tachycardia. The first step after stabilizing a patient with a tachyarrhythmia is to obtain an electrocardiogram (ECG), which is usually done at the same time as the history and physical examination are being performed. The ECG in AV nodal reentrant tachycardia will have a QRS <120 ms and P waves buried in the QRS complexes.

Tachyarrhythmias are divided based on the rhythm as regular or irregular. The QRS duration is used to classify them further. The QRS complex is, either narrow (<120 ms) or wide (≥120 ms). In general, electrical impulses generated above the ventricles (i.e. supraventricular) produce narrow QRS complexes; and impulses generated below the ventricles produce wide QRS complexes. Irregular tachyarrhythmias are more likely to occur in patients with significant cardiac or pulmonary disease.

Classification and causes of tachyarrhythmias:

  ·   Regular rhythm with narrow QRS complexes: sinus tachycardia, atrial tachycardia, AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), AV reentrant tachycardia, and atrial flutter.

  ·   Regular rhythm with wide QRS complexes: monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, and SVT with aberrancy (a supraventricular tachyarrhythmia occurring in a patient with a bundle branch block).

  ·   Irregular rhythm with narrow QRS complexes: atrial fibrillation and multifocal atrial tachycardia (typically associated with severe lung disease).

  ·   Irregular and wide QRS complexes: tachyarrhythmias most commonly represent polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (of which torsades de pointes is a specific subtype).  

Option Analysis

✅ QRS <120 ms and P waves buried in the QRS complexes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The absence of typical P waves and sawtooth waves in leads III and aVF:
Incorrect: This finding describes atrial flutter, not AV nodal reentrant tachycardia which is more likely in a young patient with no heart disease.  
❌ QRS <120 ms, irregular R-R intervals, and no visible P waves:
Incorrect: This finding describes atrial fibrillation which is an irregular rhythm. This patient has a regular rhythm palpated at the radial pulse.  
❌ QRS >120 ms and atrioventricular dissociation:
Incorrect: This finding describes monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, not AV nodal reentrant tachycardia which is more likely in this young healthy patient.  
❌ Prolonged QT interval and progressive sinusoidal alterations of the QRS axis:
Incorrect: This finding describes Torsades de pointes which is usually caused by medications. This patient takes no medications.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a one-week history of recurrent syncope. The patient states that the episodes occur when he shaves or wears a tie.
